Senator Chaney knows that it is a lot of nonsense. If there is no colour of libel in that statement, that solicitor has failed in his duty to his client in agreeing to a settlement.
—What a shocking defamatory thing to say about a lawyer, Senator.
—That is the situation. Action was not taken to prevent this petition from being presented. That was not the position at all. Action was taken to stop the libel that had been committed.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate's action today has extended the parliamentary privilege that adheres to members speaking in this chamber to people speaking outside this chamber. If anybody here makes outside this Parliament a libellous statement about anybody else, he can be sued. The privilege that Opposition senators are trying to attach to a petitioner is a privilege which members of parliament do not enjoy. So the petitioner's privilege rises above the privilege of members of parliament because the petitioner can go around libelling anybody he likes outside as long as he attaches it to a document with particular words in it, but a member of parliament cannot go outside this Parliament and libel people. So why does this chamber seek to elevate the privilege which attaches to a petitioner above the privilege that attaches to a member of parliament? The more we look at this whole process, the more ridiculous it becomes.

Senator Chaney, in his letter, talks about the Bill of Rights. The Bill of Rights protects parliamentarians and the parliamentary processes. It does not purport to protect the rights of libellers even if they put that libel in a petition. That is what Opposition senators are doing. A libel has been committed. There has been a twisting of the precedents of this House and a twisting of the law to attach privileges to somebody who wants to blackguard a former Premier of Western Australia. Senator Chaney goes on in his letter:

Any lingering doubts about this matter would appear to have been resolved by the passage of the Parliamentary Privileges Act (No. 21 of 1987) and in particular Section 16, subsections 2 (b), (c) and (d) of that Act.

I have read that provision. There is nothing in section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 which gives protection to people who libel others, whether in a petition or otherwise, outside Parliament. The Act protects evidence that is before a parliament or a parliamentary committee. No part of section 16 gives protection to a libeller of people outside Parliament. So it is a nonsense for Senator Chaney to write this in his letter:

It is my very strong view that the action taken by the former Premier is in breach of the right of citizens to circulate petitions for presentation to the Parliament. Any lingering doubts about this matter would appear to have been resolved by the passage of the Parliamentary Privileges Act . . . and in particular section 16, subsections 2 (b) (c) and (d) of that Act.
Senator Chaney either does not know his law or is writing in a way which gives a false impression. He also states in his letter:

It is also my view that the Senate must be very ready to defend the availability of recourse to the Parliament by citizens of modest means against infringement by those who are comparatively rich and powerful.

I do not believe that anybody should be denied recourse to his member of parliament. That is why members, at least on our side of the House, have their electoral offices and are available for people to come and see them. If, on the other hand, what is meant is that people should be able to present petitions to Parliament, and should be able to say what they like in those petitions without being subject to the law, that is another matter.

What Senator Chaney says is that people who present petitions should be privileged above every other citizen in the community. If someone wrote a letter to a newspaper setting out what is contained in the petition, or if someone said that on the radio, no privilege would attach. What I should like to hear from Senator Chaney is why he is interested in protecting people who circulate libellous petitions, but has no interest at all in protecting people who circulate letters or commit other forms of libel less serious than that involved here. Why should he favour one particular process rather than another? Perhaps what was envisaged in this particular case was that the matter would be raised in Parliament and made the subject of debate, and that the very purpose that Brian Burke had in taking action would be frustrated, namely, that the libel be put to rest. It is quite a tragedy-I have chosen to use that word-that this matter should be referred, as it appears it will be on the numbers, to the Privileges Committee.

I repeat that I believe it is quite wrong of the Democrats to put at risk-and that is what the Democrats quite clearly are doing-the liberty of people simply to set a precedent. This is what has been stated. It is quite wrong to make people subject to the risk of imprisonment or fines simply to establish precedent. That certainly shows no proper concern for the rights of citizens. Simply because a man has been the Premier of a State does not make him any less vulnerable to the anxieties, worries and concerns that he would have if he were subjected to this Committee and perhaps ultimately to the Senate. Nevertheless, if we are to have some interesting lines about privilege put in the books by the Democrats, so be it.

I believe that the approach taken by the Opposition, particularly the Liberal Party, is extraordinary. The letter from Senator Chaney states only half of the situation. It gives the wrong impression of what the petition really asked for. It failed to state the full extent of the petition. I should like Senator Chaney to say in reply why he did not do that; why the letter he wrote to the President failed to set out the full extent of the petition; and why it did not mention that the petition sought to delay the appointment until both Houses of the Western Australian Parliament were satisfied.

I ask Senator Chaney why he quoted section 16 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act in a context where it has no proper application at all. Section 16 clearly relates to matters which have come before this Parliament or its committees, such as evidence given before those bodies. It is quite wrong to say that it provides otherwise. The letter refers to a legal settlement since concluded with the former Premier on conditions that included collection and destruction of petition forms. There is no evidence at all that there was any agreement that the forms were to be destroyed. I call upon Senator Chaney to show where there was any agreement that the petition was to be destroyed. The letter also misrepresents the petition in so far as it says:

It is also my view that the Senate must be very ready to defend the availability of recourse to the Parliament by citizens of modest means against infringement by those who are comparatively rich and powerful.

I ask Senator Chaney why he chooses a particular class of libellers to protect against the rest of the community. I ask him to explain in what way the Senate can in any way affect the appointment of ambassadors. I ask him to explain how this Parliament can stop the recourse to law by people who wish to vindicate any rights that they believe they have. That would be the effect of his argument because if one objects to the threat of legal action, one must object to legal action itself. I ask Senator Chaney to explain what the situation would be with people living in different States if one libelled another, and the person libelled brought an action in the High Court. Could this Parliament stop the High Court hearing that case on the basis that there was a breach of privilege? Further, might it not be argued that the High Court had power to punish for contempt those who attempted to frustrate its processes by resorting to parliamentary processes?

The Opposition sits peacefully by, stopping a man resorting to what should be the right of every person in this country: to go to a court of law to have the umpire decide whether he is right or wrong. This is almost getting back to the sorts of things that used to occur with the bill of attachment. Before I conclude I should like to make clear that the Democrats, the Liberal Party and the National Party have combined here today to use their numbers to stop a person who has been grievously libelled from doing what everybody in this country should be entitled to do-to attempt to vindicate his character before the courts and either win or lose. That is what the Opposition has done.

TALK.START.PARA: —The senator knows that that is not true.

—From now on anyone who is libelled in a petition and dares to contradict or protest about what has been put in a petition will be brought before the Senate and made subject to the risk of imprisonment or being fined.
—The senator knows that that is not right.

—That is exactly what has been done. If not, I invite Senator Haines to explain how it is otherwise. It is no good protesting and saying that has not been done, because clearly the Opposition has done it.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite sure that none of the motives or purposes that, with the greatest respect, Senator Cooney attributed to the Democrats are in fact correct. I indicate to the Senate that I intend to move an amendment to the motion before the Chair. I shall do so because this is one of those rare occasions-perhaps too rare-when debate in the chamber has actually influenced the course of a matter under consideration. I was extremely unhappy about the original wording of the motion, but on the other hand was totally persuaded by Senator Macklin's comments, which I support, that the question of privilege raised by the motion with the removal of personal references should be referred on principle to the Committee for some determination.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again I believe that the entire matter of parliamentary privilege requires further extensive overhaul. Though I shall not do so, one could be unkind enough to suggest that perhaps the circumstances under which the original motion before the Chair evolved could at least in the moral sense constitute some abuse of privilege. However, I do not suggest that.

The whole question of privilege does need to be examined. Privilege, in my view, has been brought into considerable contempt-I use the word `contempt' in its simple English meaning-by the Parliament itself on a number of occasions over the years, which, of course, has resulted in a great deal of debate on the subject. The most infamous case was that in 1955 when both the publisher of a newspaper and the journalist who wrote a particular article were imprisoned in Goulburn gaol for a period of three months and served out every day of their sentences. I noted when I read the transcript of that matter that a very young and new member of the then Opposition, by the name of E. G. Whitlam-a man I respect enormously-voted in favour of those prison sentences being imposed. I intend one day to ask Gough why he did that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look in Souter's book.
—It is in Souter's book, is it?
—You never met Frank Browne; that is obvious. He was a grub.

—I never met him, but I am perfectly prepared to say on the evidence before me that he was a grub and a scurrilous person. But I do not think that people who are grubs should be sent to gaol. There would be a lot of us in deep trouble if that were the case. Having been persuaded by Senator Macklin that this matter should be looked at, I drafted the amendment with that in mind, to remove the personal references from the motion.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to members of the Senate that the whole question of privilege has been examined by the relevant committee of the Constitutional Commission inquiring into potential amendments to the Australian Constitution. One of the recommendations of that committee is that consideration should be given to overhauling the entire question of parliamentary privilege and having its limits defined in very precise terms in the Australian Constitution. That is a proposition with which I concur, the extent of my concurrence being with the need to examine the possibility of having a constitutional amendment defining precisely the limits of parliamentary privilege. Parliamentary privilege will remain a respectable institution only if it is accorded respect and not abused by the members of parliament upon whom it is conferred. I think I would have a fair amount of support in saying that the infamous case of Fitzpatrick in 1955 in the House of Representatives was one in which privilege was abused by the Parliament and extended in a way that I hope will never be done again. The amendment is self-explanatory. I move:

Leave out all words after `Committee of Privileges', insert `whether the circulation of a petition containing defamatory material for the purpose of gaining signatures and subsequent submission to the Senate is or ought to be privileged and how such issues should be determined and in what forum'.

I point out to honourable senators that I included the words `defamatory material' in this amendment at the suggestion of the Australian Democrats. The final words, which I support, as to the question of how such issues should be determined and in what forum, were included at the suggestion of the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney. I think it is a proper reference to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is going to determine first whether the material is defamatory?

—I will get onto that now. I had some concerns, and I think Senator Chaney was a party to my voicing them, about the inclusion of the words `defamatory material' because of that very question. I must say that, had I been left to my druthers, I druther have left the wording in the original form, which simply read, `whether the circulation of a petition for the purpose of gaining signatures' so that the question of principle could be resolved. But because I am seeking the support of the Senate for this proposition, and because I am a reasonable man, I acceded to the suggestion.

SPEECH.PARA: To answer Senator Puplick's question as to whether the petition contained defamatory material, that would be put beyond doubt if, subsequent to the circulation of the petition, the matter were determined in a court of law and the court came down with a judgment that the material complained of-I imagine that a complaint would have to be lodged in that circumstance-was in fact defamatory. But I would not rule out the possibility of the Senate itself, as it obviously has the power to do at any time, taking exception to the material or, having had brought to its attention an allegation concerning possible defamatory material, referring the matter on its own motion to the Committee of Privileges. In that instance that determination could be made by the Senate, not acting as a court of law but simply indicating that there was a prima-facie case that the material was defamatory.

Those are the two circumstances in which I would envisage such a determination could be made in a legal and a definitive sense by a court of law, should action be taken. I totally support Senator Macklin's comment, as I am sure every honourable senator in this chamber would, that under no circumstances should this Parliament seek, by exercising privilege-which I think would be a gross abuse of privilege-to prevent someone who was grossly defamed by a petition from taking the legal action that is his right.

I was alarmed in the true sense of the word by the wording of the original motion that came before this House. In a way I am glad that this matter has been raised, because it is one that should be looked at. I again advise honourable senators who are interested in this whole question of privilege, as all members of parliament should be, to refer to the suggestions of the committee of the Constitutional Commission on enshrining limits to the powers of privilege by amendment to the Constitution. It is probably appropriate that we look at that. I would be absolutely alarmed and horrified to think that a grossly defamatory statement affecting a person's credit and standing in the community could be written on a piece of paper, topped and tailed with the appropriate prayer and, set out in the proper order and form of a petition, laid on the counter of every store and public place in the community. Thousands of copies could be printed and circulated for 12 months, it could be grossly damaging to a person's credibility but, because it is in the correct form of a petition, it could be covered by parliamentary privilege. No legal redress would, therefore, be available to the person defamed.

I refer again to the point that I thought was made very succinctly by the Minister for Home Affairs, Senator Robert Ray, when he said that such a petition could refer to people who are not members of parliament and who have absolutely no personal right of redress in parliament to put the record straight. If the document were covered by privilege, such a person would have no legal redress, in contrast to a case of a normal defamatory statement being printed. It is indeed a moot point. I for one am pleased that it is to be examined by the Committee of Privileges. I make no bones about stating the manner in which I think it should be resolved, not in the particular case involved but in terms of principle.

We are all familiar with the gossip that goes around about people in public life, and it is appalling to think that anyone could seriously put forward the view that I could draft the most libellous suggestions about a member of parliament, saying for example that that person was a sexual deviate and that on those grounds, as a member of the `moral majority' organisation, I was seeking the assistance of members of parliament to expel that person from the Parliament, as the Parliament has the power to do. I could then go on, under the situation that perhaps some people in the course of this debate have suggested might be possible, to describe in graphic detail the extent, purpose and type of sexual deviancy that was involved. I think it would be an appalling proposition if that person were prevented from taking the legal action that would, under any other circumstance, be available to him because I had topped and tailed that garbage and nonsense and presented it in the correct form as a petition.

In closing, I take on board the concern that Senator Cooney expressed-and I think this is a proper concern-about whether we should be using people as sacrificial lambs simply to establish for our convenience and, I think, frankly, for the good of the community a precedent as to how this matter should be determined. I do not think that is proper or principled. Therefore, I think the form of words taking out the personal references in the original motion is the acceptable form that should be used. However, I wish to make it absolutely clear-I have taken advice on this and I believe that advice to be correct-that the removal of personal references would not preclude in any sense whatever the Committee, of its own motion, choosing to have brought before it people who may well be concerned with the case in point. This is simply a matter of principle that has to be determined. In fact, let me say, for what it is worth, that if I were a member of the Committee, it would make eminent sense to me in terms of examining some topical material to examine the particular case that has been brought before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying, Senator, that in the event of their not bringing this case before them for consideration, you would use the procedures of this place to ensure that they did?

—No. I thought I was putting it much more moderately than that and I am sorry that what I said has been misunderstood. I would not force anyone into doing it. I say it again: if I were a member of the Committee, I would simply think it a matter of commonsense that in terms of--
—This place could, if it chose to ignore the specific case and the principles as well as the principles involved, direct the Committee to take it on board.

—I agree with that. The Senate has the power to give directions to any of its committees at any time it wishes and nothing can interfere with that. I am saying that if one were having a look at the cases that lay under this reference, it would obviously be sensible to have a look at the one that was most topical. The Committee could decide that it wants to do that. The Committee is not precluded from doing that should it determine that that is what it should do. The Committee may also decide that it wants to do a considerable amount of research and discuss the question in general before it investigates cases. That, I might add, is a matter for the Committee itself.

SPEECH.PARA: As has already been pointed out properly in debate, not only is the Committee subject to any reference that could properly be made to it by the Senate, but also, of course, it cannot dictate itself how the matter should be dealt with. Whatever the Committee determines should happen can only come back to this place as a recommendation from the Committee. It will be the Senate itself that determines whether any definitive action will be taken by the Senate in response to that reference. Having said all that, I would simply ask the Senate to support my amendment to Senator Chaney's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, in light of what I understand will be your position on the Privileges Committee, it is probably very fitting that you are in the chair and are thereby precluded from participating in this debate. I would like to respond to Senator Collins's amendment. Some of the discussion in the chamber has made following the debate more difficult than it would otherwise have been. While Senator Cooney was speaking, Senator Collins and I were talking to the Australian Democrats. Because of that, I must say that I was not able to follow completely some elements of the debate. At this stage I will purely address myself to Senator Collins's amendment rather than to the other elements of the debate that has taken place.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins has proposed the sending off to the Privileges Committee of a quite general reference on the issues which are raised by the matter contained in my motion. The amendment that he has put down is in very broad terms. His amendment seeks to insert the following words:

Whether the circulation of a petition containing defamatory material for the purpose of gaining signatures and subsequent submission to the Senate is or ought to be privileged and how such issues should be determined and in what forum.

I agree with Senator Collins's personal opinion, which has not been reflected in the wording of his amendment, that, in a sense, describing the material as defamatory material begs the question. One of the most difficult issues in this is the question of whether or not something is defamatory.

What I heard of Senator Cooney's speech took me back to the magistrates courts in a quite forceful way. I heard him address the question of this material. I would have to say that his view as to the defamatory nature of this petition and mine are starkly at odds. He described the material in terms that I would regard as highly excessive. I read the petition once in the course of this debate. I believe that it would be a very tender soul who would regard the contents of that petition as being defamatory. But that is not a matter that we should be focusing on. The point is simply brought out that the determination of whether or not something is defamatory is a difficult matter. It is a legal matter and opinions in this place will differ and do not matter anyway.

What concerns me about the amendment that Senator Collins has moved is its very generality. If we look at the development of the law of privilege, we will find in fact that the Parliament has been forced to address itself to particular cases. Although Labor senators have expressed some abhorrence at the fact that specific people have been brought into this-in this case, on the one hand the complaining would-be petitioner and, on the other hand the ex-Premier of Western Australia-the reality is that all of the precedents in this area relate to individual cases which have been addressed by the Parliament. The whole body of law on privilege had been, until our own legislation of last year, built up on an examination of particular cases.

My worry about the generality of what has been proposed by Senator Collins is twofold. My first concern is that he is setting the Committee an impossible task by asking it to try to cover fully what is such a generalised reference. My second concern, though, is that this generalisation could enable the Committee to avoid the particular concerns that I have raised in my motion. I listened very carefully to what Senator Collins had to say and to the exchange between Senator Collins and the Australian Democrats during his speech when the question was raised of whether or not the petitioner in this case could come forward and give to the Committee of Privileges the facts of his case and why he is concerned. Senator Collins said that he wanted to make it clear-he had taken advice on this-that the removal of the reference to the persons involved in the present case does not preclude the Committee, of its own motion, from having the persons before it. The rub, of course, is that this matter may or may not be acceded to by the Committee. That is why the Australian Democrats raised the point that the Senate could direct the Committee to hear a matter if there appeared to be a case of injustice.

I would suggest to Senator Collins that an alternative approach would in fact be preferable. I would ask the Australian Democrats in particular to consider this alternative approach. I believe that it is perfectly in accordance with the way in which Parliament has successfully dealt with privilege matters in the past that the particular matter of concern is dealt with as a particular matter of concern. One goes, then, from the particular to the general principle which has been distilled. There is nothing odd about that. The whole of the common law has been built up on that same principle. I would suggest that it would be sounder to leave my motion as it is and, if it is wished to ensure that the general principles that are sought to be adduced are dealt with, to add Senator Collins's words to my motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —That destroys the amendment and the purpose of it.

—The reality is that there is, I think, at least a danger that the amendment in the form put forward by Senator Collins will in fact present both an impossible task to the Committee, because of its very generality, and a risk that it will not be able to come to grips with the particular complaint which has given this issue some clarity.
—Should they be so foolish, the Senate can redress that.

—I would like to make sure that what Senator Collins has just said is on the record. I am sure that it will be now. I think it is very important that that point is clear because it would appear that the support that Senator Collins is giving his own amendment, which is likely to be shared by other members of the Australian Labor Party, is on the basis of assuming that the Committee will be accessible to this person if he wishes to come forward and put his case as to why the Senate should deal with this situation. I believe that that access is absolutely vital. It lies in the hands of the citizen concerned as to whether he should avail himself of that. That is his decision. The Opposition believes that the particular case should be dealt with. We have no objection to the addition of those words, but on that basis we will oppose the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Enough has been said in this debate to indicate that there are real difficulties, even in respect of a narrow examination. In his speech, the Minister for Home Affairs (Senator Robert Ray) made a great deal of the rights of people to sue for defamation. If honourable senators look at my speech in this place, they will find that I made the point that we are dealing with a competing set of rights. There is the right of the Parliament and the right of the citizen in respect of the Parliament; there are the rights of individuals to protect themselves against defamatory statements. There is no suggestion by the Opposition that there are not difficulties in marrying those two rights and I believe that, if we try to deal with this matter on the basis of dealing with every case that might come before us, there is a real risk of failure. I also think that if we are dealing with this matter in the abstract, which enables Senator Collins to say that he is alarmed and horrified that a gross and defamatory statement could be distributed because of this procedure, then we run the risk that this particular case will be regarded as one of a gross and defamatory statement in circumstances in which I believe that that would be quite inaccurate.

I was somewhat puzzled by Senator Cooney's suggestion that the settlement of this case in some way indicated to the Senate that the solicitors involved had agreed that the matter involved a defamatory statement. If Senator Cooney has had no experience of parties having to settle litigation because they simply cannot financially afford that litigation, then he has had a very narrow practice indeed. I think that anyone who has had any experience in the law in Australia knows that it is beyond the capacity of many middle income Australians to pay the costs involved and on that basis they must avoid litigation. If Senator Cooney has had such a sheltered practice in Victoria that he has never come across such a case, then all I can say is that I envy him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying that that is why it was settled?

—I do not know that, nor does anybody. There have been so many conflicting assertions of fact in this debate that one can only say that a proper examination of those facts by a committee is the only way to settle the matter. Senator Cooney's and Senator Robert Ray's assertions are all based on their information, just as my assertions are based on the information that has been provided to me. I do not believe that in this forum those issues can be finally determined.
—It would be an extraordinary thing if somebody could libel somebody else, believing it was true, and then withdraw with an apology.

—That is a relatively simple-minded observation. For Senator Cooney to suggest that the withdrawal of a statement believed to be true under threat of legal proceedings means that that person has changed his mind and believes the statement is no longer true is a quite extraordinary statement. The simple point that I have been making-and I am surprised that Senator Cooney is not prepared to concede it-is that the cost of litigation is a factor in determining how people behave in many of these circumstances. If he does not understand that, then he does not understand the problem which is being brought forward in this case.

SPEECH.PARA: We have here a quite simple set of facts which a long debate cannot obscure. The reality is that a petition, in terms which have been read out in this Parliament, was circulated by an Australian citizen. That petition was withdrawn under circumstances which have been canvassed in this debate-circumstances involving the threat of legal proceedings for defamation. As a result of that settlement there was a collecting up of petitions and, as I understand it, the destruction of some of them. Costs were paid to the ex-Premier of Western Australia. The problem which this Senate has to face is that the proper access of Australian citizens to this Parliament can be denied by the use of legal process in cases where there is simply an alleged defamation. In those circumstances, for us to turn our backs on the matter and take the view that that is not a problem is to ignore reality. I believe that there has been an ignoring of that reality in much of the debate that has taken place this morning.

On behalf of the Opposition, I oppose the amendment moved by Senator Collins. I again ask the Australian Democrats to consider the fact that privilege matters have always been dealt with on the basis of moving from the particular to the general. In this case there should be no suggestion that the particular case is not to be examined because it is one which I believe raises very serious issues, not only for the citizen concerned but also for other Australians who might be involved in petitioning. It is not enough for both Senator Ray and Senator Cooney to say with great heat that it cannot or should not be asserted that an Australian can circulate grossly defamatory material with impunity in the form of a petition. They have not addressed themselves to the issue of what happens if an Australian wishes to circulate material which is not defamatory but faces the prospect of expensive, drawn out legal proceedings to prove that point. That is a simple, practical method of blocking access to this Parliament. In the debate which has taken place neither Senator Ray, who led for the Government, nor Senator Cooney, who I think-to do him justice-filled in time to some extent to allow consideration of an amendment and spoke for his full 30 minutes, probably at the request of the Minister for Home Affairs, paid attention to that very significant, practical problem which can face citizens of limited means trying to get access to this Parliament. That is a very serious problem.

I do not believe that Senator Collins's amendment is the best way of ensuring that the Privileges Committee looks at the real difficulties which this case raises. It would be far too easy, on a generalised reference, to take the simple view that if something is defamatory it should not be circulated. That is far too neat for the issues raised by the present case. We have here a situation which requires that we ensure that somebody is not denied his rights to come to this Parliament by the use of the threat of legal proceedings which economics preclude being determined by the courts.

I am sure that this matter will be concluded without too much more debate. I see that Senator Burns is here. He is one who takes a keen interest in these debates. I say to him, as a senator representing people who do not have a lot of money, that he and other Labor senators are in a position to show some sympathy for the real problems of people of limited means who are up against people who have relatively greater means. I used to think that the Australian Labor Party had great concerns about that balance in our society. I see very little evidence of it in this debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue at hand is the amendment moved by Senator Collins. Senator Collins is seeking to substitute the general principle for the particular case. I indicate that that would have our support. In answer to some of the points raised by Senator Chaney, I note that his motion did not require the Standing Committee of Privileges to call either Strickland or Burke. In fact, the Committee can do what it likes. It would be very odd not to have them called, I admit, but it would have no obligation and no requirement to call them. In fact, it would not even have a requirement to tell them that a hearing was being conducted. Some of the members of the Committee have been sitting in the chamber throughout the entire debate and are very much aware of what the issues are. I believe it would be very odd to go into a general inquiry without looking at that specific item. I raise a particular point, which is that the motion refers to looking at defamatory material; I think that is the crux of the matter. It also asks how that will be determined and where. Fairly obviously, as Senator Collins pointed out, at least on the first glance one assumes that it will be in the courts.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chaney quite rightly has an additional concern in that in the case to which he referred he maintains that there is no court action. As I understand it, there has not been a court hearing on it, so a court has not made a determination on whether the material was defamatory. The parties have come to an agreement by the issuing of an apology; hence it is not likely to get to court. So there is a further item, which I am quite sure needs to be picked up, of material which somebody is claiming to be defamatory. I do not perceive that any responsible committee of this chamber would go into an inquiry and not pick up those types of nuances and deal with the issue once and for all. One of the saving graces of this chamber is that our committees do do a thorough job when they deal with these issues. In fact, all the issues with which I have been involved on the Privileges Committee have been dealt with in the most thorough and comprehensive manner, picking up items that had not even been referred to in debate, let alone those items that had been referred to in debate.

So I am quite sure that the Committee will look at the specific issue. I am sure that it will advise Mr Burke and Mr Strickland that it is looking at this, and I presume it will probably invite them to make submissions to and even appear before it, if that seems to fit in with the operation, which I think it does. What the general will do for the particular is to remove Senator Cooney's--

TALK.START.PARA: —What if it refuses to hear a submission?

—If it refused to hear one, we have other mechanisms to deal with that at a later date. But this does satisfy Senator Cooney's proposition-which I must admit I did feel had substance-in that we are not necessarily going to string up anybody. I think he put it a little strongly and went a little over the top; certainly some parts were simply false, particularly the last part where he said that this would go on for evermore. If the Committee made a determination, presumably this would not happen again one way or the other, unless Senator Cooney was postulating that both the courts and the Senate Privileges Committee would be ignored. I do not think that would happen, and hence any determination that is likely to be made would satisfy that. I think that addressing the general issue would get us back a recommendation that would satisfy this. Senator Chaney should be satisfied because the particular items will have to be rehearsed. That is, as it were, one step down from defamatory material in that it relates to material which somebody is claiming to be defamatory and which has gone through some type of reconciliation process-irrespective of whether it was forced, to use Senator Chaney's terms, or given freely of the person's own accord because the person was wrong. I do not know the substance of the situation so am not able to judge that, and I do not think that I should in any event.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment states `whether the circulation of a petition containing defamatory material for the purpose of gaining signatures and subsequent submission to the Senate is or ought to be privileged and how such issues should be determined and in what forum'. I think that covers all of the principle matters that have been raised here today. In Senator Chaney's first speech what he was interested in was satisfying the principle matters. He should be satisfied that the principle matters will now be addressed.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Collins's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion, as amended, agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill extends further the care that the Federal Government has for this country's natural resources. It is proper that it should because this country needs protection. It is proper to take action in the year of the Bicentenary to help atone for the years of disrespect, ill treatment and exploitation of one of the most marvellous continents. That has not always been so. For perhaps 3,000 generations before the arrival of the Europeans, Aborigines evolved a practice of customary behaviour and an extremely rich ritual and psychic life to create a relatively harmonious membership of the Australian environment.
—Why do they always put you on a suicide mission?
—Senator Boswell says that it is a suicide mission. Unless I subject myself to this, he will commit the forests, the natural life and the great heritage of this country to death.
—Tell us about the working man you are supposed to be representing.

—What is being said about the working man and the working woman is this: because this Government is intent on protecting this country, not only for its present generation but also for those of the future, it follows as a matter of course that some people will be put out of work. To say that they are being put out of work because legislation is diminishing this country's resources is, of course, incorrect. The reality is that logging has taken place over the past century or so and the resources have dwindled because of overuse. The Northern Rainforest Management Agency (NORMA) was set up by the Queensland Government to fight the World Heritage listing of the wet tropical rainforests. A report of that study was presented to a recent meeting of NORMA's scientific committee. Under the heading `Summary' the report, in part, reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee found that out of the 167,000 hectares allocated for logging by the Forestry Department, 126,000 hectares or three-quarters of the area was of such high conservation significance that it should not be logged.
This would reduce the timber industry to 25 per cent of its 1987 level.
That report was prepared by the Northern Rainforest Management Agency, which was set up by the Queensland Government to fight World Heritage listing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. The honourable senator said that he had quoted from a NORMA document. That opinion was not NORMA's opinion; it was the opinion of one man in NORMA and it was overruled by NORMA.
—That is not a point of order.

—That is simply a matter of fact. Senator Boswell has already spoken and we will not hear his brilliance again in this debate. Perhaps an honourable senator following me in this debate will correct that, if Senator Boswell feels that it should be corrected. Is Senator Boswell saying that no part of Queensland is worth saving for future generations? Is that what he, one of the foremost senators from Queensland, is saying? The reality is that jobs are being lost in Queensland and other areas, but that is because the resources are being taken from the people and sold overseas and in Australia. Because of the way the forests have been used over the years, we are being robbed of not only our great heritage but also the very resources which the Opposition purports to want to save. Of course, people who lose their jobs must be sympathised with grandly. This Government is doing something about that, in terms of not only those who will be affected directly by legislation but also those who are affected by the dwindling of resources as a result of the use to which they have been put over the years. This Government has created one million jobs since it came into power.
—Talk about the Bill.

—It is interesting that, when we talk about the Bill, the Opposition asks, `What about the jobs?'. When we talk about jobs, on the invitation of the Opposition, and show that this Government has acted mightily in terms of creating jobs, the Opposition becomes embarrassed because we have shown that the Government has created jobs and that jobs are available for those who have been made redundant by our forestry policies, so it asks us to talk about something else. Why does the Opposition want this Government to talk about anything but the great success it has had in creating jobs or its economic record? At the same time, the Government has created a legislative basis for the preservation of this country so that the generation that follows us will benefit from it and enjoy it. That is the sort of thing in which the Opposition is disappointed. This Government-the Fraser Government which preceded it was unable to do so-has created an economic basis for this country's future growth and, at the same time, has preserved the environment so that those who will benefit from our economic policies will be able to enjoy not only the prosperity that this Government is bringing but also the beauty that will be preserved in the nation. That is what we are all about. We have combined the two things. The difficulty that the opposition falls into is this: it says, `Look, those two things cannot go together. You have to create jobs, and thereby ruin the environment, or preserve the environment and thereby diminish jobs'.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that as from today the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Senator Bolkus, is the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, Mr Howe, for the purpose of answering questions in this chamber, instead of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson.

—I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to Mr Mick Young's appointment as a $1,000 a day consultant to Qantas Airways Ltd. I ask: Was Qantas advised before making this appointment that Mr Young had been cleared of any wrongdoing in the Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd affair? If so, who gave that advice to Qantas and on what basis was such information made available to Qantas?

—As to the quantum of the consultancy payment proposed to be made to Mr Young, I do not accept the figure that Senator Baume uses. The figure of $1,000 a day is the figure that has been cited by Mr Beale. It has been responded to by Qantas, which has said that the figure in question is grossly exaggerated. I would have thought that if there is a degree of decency on the part of members of the Opposition in this respect, rather than, as I have said before, a vulgar, opportunistic desire to try to derive some political capital out of deliberate misstatement of the truth, that is for their consciences. As to whether Qantas was advised of anything in relation to the Harris-Daishowa affair, I have absolutely no idea whatsoever. As I have said previously, I regarded it-as the Prime Minister regarded the whole question of the possible appointment of Mr Young by Qantas-as a matter for the commercial judgment of that particular company. I did not seek to intervene or involve myself in any way, nor have I made any inquiries as to what information that company may have had or may have regarded as relevant to its appointment in question.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. I ask: What is the most recent information in relation to the growth in employment of wage and salary earners? What is the growth rate for employment of wage and salary earners in Australia? What information can the Minister provide in relation to the relative performance of the States in this area and the causes of any differences in relative performances?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most recent information regarding the growth in employment of wage and salary earners is in the Australian Bureau of Statistics figures for the September quarter of 1987 which were released in February. They show that the growth rate nationally is 3.3 per cent. Within that national average figure there is a wide range of performance between the States and Territories, varying from a figure of minus 4 per cent in the Northern Territory and a low figure of 1.7 per cent in Queensland to 4.1 per cent in New South Wales and 4 1/2 per cent in South Australia. ANSWER.PARA: The causes of the discrepancy in those performances I suggest are not very hard to pinpoint, that is, that the Northern Territory and Queensland have pretty incompetent non-Labor governments; the two States I mentioned as having the highest growth rates have competent Labor governments. I think that the messages behind that ought to be pretty clear to the people in New South Wales, that is, if they want to repeat in New South Wales the sort of thing that has been happening in Queensland and the Northern Territory over recent years, they should vote for the same sort of government as the Northern Territory and Queensland have.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HARRIS-DAISHOWA (AUSTRALIA) PTY LTD: DONATION TO THE AUSTRALIAN LABOR PARTY

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K. .

—I ask whether the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories will comment on the scuttling of the Nella Dan and the suggestion by the honourable member for Bass, Mr Warwick Smith, that everything possible was not done to minimise the losses to the Commonwealth.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. The Nella Dan ran aground at Macquarie Island on 3 December in strong winds, which are not uncommon for Macquarie Island at that time of the year or, indeed, any other time of the year. Some 60 per cent of the cargo for Macquarie Island had already been unloaded. Most of the portable scientific equipment-five to six tonnes of it-and the cargo were removed manually from the grounded vessel by volunteer expeditioners in difficult conditions. The balance of the station's fuel was pumped ashore, as I think I said in answer to another question here last year, using station equipment. It is understandable that the heavy cargo and equipment could not be removed, given that the lifting gear was inoperative due to the conditions prevailing at the time.

ANSWER.PARA: A salvage operation was mounted by the ship's owners. I think Mr Smith is confused rather badly about who owned the ship in the first place. The Lauritzen line used an Australian salvage company and a chartered rig supply vessel to attempt the salvage. So we saw a re-floating and the removal of oil; and an expert assessment was provided to the owners by those who would know a little more about such matters than Mr Smith. The owners decided, therefore, that on practical and financial grounds there was no option but to scuttle. That was done at 5.42 on 24 December 1987 under a sea dumping permit issued by me as the responsible Minister. The Department of Transport and Communications officer designated in the permit has certified that the dumping took place, as far as was practical, within the terms of the permit. That minor discrepancy occurred only because a bit of a problem was encountered in the scuttling. There was a severe list in the vessel and fire had broken out on board as well. We are still awaiting the outcome of the inquiry of the Department of Transport and Communications into the incident.

The extent of the Commonwealth's loss and its legal position on that loss is currently being assessed by my Department in consultation with the Attorney-General's Department. The reality is that at the end of the day, when it is not your ship, it is not your job to assess whether the vessel can or should be re-floated or towed back to Australia. If it is the considered opinion of experts that scuttling is the only course available, scuttling is what takes place. That is what happened on this occasion. Someone ought to tell Mr Smith that he is barking up the wrong tree.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer also to statements made in the Senate by the Minister as follows: on 17 September 1985, claiming that Australia's bilateral safeguards treaties ensure `that Australian uranium is not being diverted for use in nuclear weapons by France or any other state'; on 22 August 1986, claiming that the EURATOM safeguards system verifies `that nuclear material supplied for peaceful purposes is not diverted to military or nuclear purposes'; on 1 May 1986, claiming that he-the Minister-could `guarantee that no Australian uranium stays in the USSR'; on 5 May 1986, claiming that France has not used Australian uranium tails in the Superphenix reactor. I ask: First, given that EURATOM has deliberately violated Australia's safeguards agreements, apparently without the Government's knowledge, does the Minister agree that these previous statements by him are either false or unable to be proved to be true by the Australian Government? Second, does the Minister agree that the Government does not know how Australian uranium is used once it leaves Australia? If it is just a re-run of some of the allegations which were made some little time ago and which were the subject of earlier and detailed investigation which did not lead me in any way to change the substance of statements I made earlier as Minister for Resources and Energy, obviously I stand by what I said. If the report amounts to some new allegation which comes from a credible source, obviously the report will have to be the subject of investigation and further response. The most I can undertake to do in the present circumstances, unless Senator Cook has some further information in his capacity as Minister for Resources, is to refer the matter to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and see what further reply he is able to make.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a Press release issued yesterday by Australian Democrat Senator Janet Powell in which she proposes that the charter of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation be extended and that it take over the now defunct Times on Sunday newspaper? Can the Minister provide any information as to the cost to the Commonwealth Budget of such a proposal?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the statement referred to by Senator Schacht. Indeed, I have a copy of it here. It refers to the desperate need for a newspaper free from any possibility of editorial intereference. That was not a slip of the tongue; it is spelt i-n-t-e-r-e-f-e-r-e-n-c-e. So I can only assume that the degree of editorial freedom or non-editorial involvement proposed should also extend to not correcting spelling errors. How a newspaper that did not have any editorial management, editorial interference, editorial intereference, or however one likes to put it, could function realistically is beyond my comprehension. It seems to me that if there was no control, no management, no responsibility and no accountability any newspaper staff would be a little like a bunch of headless chooks-or, indeed, some might be unkind enough to say a little like the Democrats themselves.

ANSWER.PARA: I have been asked about the financial consequences of such a proposal. I understand that the Times on Sunday has been losing about $9m a year. There is a rather unkind joke circulating in Sydney which takes the form of the question, `How do you start a small business?'. The answer is, `You give Warwick Fairfax a big business'. Whatever truth, if any, there may be in that, the losses sustained by the Times on Sunday go back to well before the period that Mr Fairfax Junior took over the management of the John Fairfax company. If the index of internal managerial efficiency and other efficiency which the Australian Broadcasting Corporation displayed were to be superimposed on the longstanding losses of that newspaper, I think the possibility for that figure to multiply would be pretty high, and the losses sustained by the Commonwealth would be a multiple of $9m a year. TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer the Minister to reports that Australian Federal Police (AFP) phone tap material relating to the activities of murdered drug dealer Tony `Spaghetti' Eustace was not made available to the coronial inquiry into his death. I refer the Minister also to the fact that that material is alleged to reveal approaches by Eustace to a woman who, in return for the promise of financial assistance, agreed to approach the late Mr Justice Murphy on Eustace's behalf. Is it a fact that, as reported, this information was available to the commission of inquiry into the conduct of the late judge? The material was the product of listening devices installed during a major drug investigation. It was recorded by the AFP under the provisions of the Customs Act 1901. Material of relevance to possible State offences was passed by the AFP to the New South Wales Police soon after it became available. Recent Press articles have also purported to quote from transcripts of recordings made by the AFP under the provisions of the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1959. —By a happy coincidence, Mr President, my question is almost a supplementary question to that asked by Senator Haines and it is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the Minister aware of recent allegations in the news magazine Der Spiegel of illegal arrangements between the European Atomic Energy Community and the West German nuclear processing company unfortunately named Nukem, resulting in the exchange of certificates of origin for uranium controlled by EURATOM? Can the Minister inform the chamber of any investigations being undertaken by officials of the Australian Safeguards Office into this very serious matter? QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CRIMINAL ACTIVITY BY AUSTRALIAN CITIZENS IN THE PHILIPPINES

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. During his visit to the Philippines he talked about the presence in that country of Australians engaged in criminal or other undesirable activities. Apart from the signing of the extradition treaty, what has Australia done and what will Australia do to rectify the situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have been given an opportunity to comment on the importance of the signing last week of the extradition treaty in Manila between the Government of Australia and the Government of the Philippines. It was a most significant step. It was the first such extradition treaty signed between Australia and a South East Asian country. It closes off safe havens and places of retreat for Australian criminals which have been well documented by various royal commissions. Indeed, a cursory understanding of the underworld in Manila would reveal that Australians have established for themselves a niche in the prostitution and gambling world there and also in drug trafficking. That creates a very unfortunate image of Australians in the Philippines. I was told by Embassy officials that not only does it affect decent Australian businessmen trying to conduct business in the Philippines but also it creates a more general bad impression of Australians amongst ordinary Filipinos, particularly in Manila and other major places.

ANSWER.PARA: My visit to the Philippines was part of a visit to South East Asia, including Thailand, which was directed precisely to closing off these safe havens. With the signing of the extradition treaty, we believe that we will be able to extradite those who have committed offences in Australia and fled to the Philippines in order to escape the arm of our law. We intend to follow up the momentum established by the signing of this treaty. We have had very successful discussions on the conclusion of the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Treaty, and I believe that the support of the Justice Secretary, Mr Ordonez, and President Aquino, to whom I mentioned this matter, was immediate, and I am sure that it will be facilitated within the Philippines Executive and parliamentary wings.

This will enable us to track down the assets of Australian criminals and drug traffickers who have removed their assets to the Philippines to enable, upon conviction in Australia for an offence, those assets to be confiscated by the Philippines Government and returned to Australia into our national coffers as they ought to be. Mutually, of course, it will also assist the Philippines Government to recover any Marcos assets in Australia. It is known that certain assets-real estate and otherwise-are held by cronies of Marcos in Australia. Of course, that was a major factor in the interest shown by President Aquino and others in this possibility.

It is also the case, and it is worth mentioning, that I was extremely impressed by the very excellent relations between the law enforcement agencies in the Philippines, the Australian Federal Police (AFP) and the Australian Customs Service. I believe that that excellent relationship, which has led to the putting of people under surveillance and to notifying Australian law enforcement authorities of the fact that certain criminals and drug traffickers are leaving the Philippines and entering Australia for the purposes of drug trafficking, has led to arrests and charges which I think most Australians are aware of. Our AFP liaison officer in the Philippines is doing an excellent job and that is just one more element in the very good relationship we are building up with South East Asian countries in relation to law enforcement in the region. Criminals do not recognise national boundaries, and we, in our fight against organised crime, must adopt the same approach.

Secondly, as a result of her answer will she undertake to obtain confirmation from Mr Unsworth of the remarks which he undoubtedly made and has repeated? Either at the end of Question Time today or prior to Question Time tomorrow will the Minister respond to the question that she has been asked?

I shall check the validity of what Senator Puplick is claiming and I shall be happy to answer at the end of Question Time.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to reports in last week's media concerning a survey conducted by the Government on domestic violence in Australia. Does the survey indicate that domestic violence is a major problem in this country?

—I saw the reports to which Senator Crowley referred. It is an extraordinarily sad fact that the survey carried out in December 1987 on community attitudes towards domestic violence revealed that there is a very high tolerance by Australians to domestic violence. The survey was the first step towards the development of a three year education campaign aimed at reducing the incidence of domestic violence in the community. Because it is recognised that domestic violence affects all groups in society, it has been decided that the campaign will include measures appropriate to communities in both rural and urban areas, to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island groups and to people of a non-English speaking background. A Commonwealth-State task force on domestic violence has been established to provide a consultative network and to take into account work already undertaken, including legislative changes in the States and Territories.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: NEW SOUTH WALES PREMIER'S COMMENTS ON THE MINISTER FOR FINANCE

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance. By way of preface I refer to the report in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald of certain comments made by the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Barrie Unsworth, in a television interview last night for Channel 9's A Current Affair. First, is it appropriate to refer to the Minister, as Mr Unsworth did last night, as `some sort of wheat farmer from Western Australia'? Even if it is appropriate, will the Minister join with me in condemning this slur upon the good name of wheat farmers, whether from Western Australia or any- where else? Secondly, is it true to say, as Mr Unsworth said last night, that the Minister `hasn't got much association with the Labor Party'? If so why has the Minister been concealing that fact from all of us-Mr Unsworth apart-for all these years? Finally, will the Minister agree that honourable senators should carefully heed the advice implicit in Mr Unsworth's rhetorical question, `Senator Walsh? Who takes any notice of Senator Walsh'?

—I did not read the Sydney Morning Herald this morning. Unlike the assumption made in reply to an earlier question, I shall take Senator Stone's word that he has correctly quoted those parts of the interview. I do not think is for me to judge whether it is fair for Mr Unsworth to call me some sort of wheat farmer from Western Australia. I have not called myself a wheat farmer for the best part of 14 years. I have put that in the past tense. I suppose I could be called some sort of wheat farmer from Western Australia, even if only in the past tense, just as Senator Stone could be called some sort of wheat farmer's son from Western Australia, or the son of some sort of wheat farmer from Western Australia. —My question is directed to the Minister for Consumer Affairs. Is the Minister aware that there is widespread community concern about items of household furniture which are highly flammable? Is it true that this problem poses a serious risk of death to house occupants as a result of toxic fumes produced in the event of a house fire?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem that Senator McMullan has raised is well known to the Government. It is known that certain materials used in the construction of household items, especially plastics, will burn very readily and may produce toxic gases which can kill people very quickly. The concern is basically because of the widespread use of polyurethane foam, which is a relatively cheap filling. The foam is used in quite a number of padded furniture items such as lounge chairs and mattresses. It is a material that ignites readily and produces gases, including carbon monoxide and hydrogen cyanide. Obviously it has a fatal effect in the event of fire.

ANSWER.PARA: Fire authorities in Australia have already expressed concern about the fact that such materials greatly increase the risk of death in house fires, and are concerned also that most fire deaths result from asphyxiation rather than burns. Public awareness of the situation has been heightened by events in the United Kingdom and the United States of America. In recent days in the United States particularly there have been quite a number of deaths involving toxic fumes from polyurethane. I think that 24 deaths were reported in the period from December 1987 to January 1988.

The Government is looking at a number of ways of addressing this problem. It has the example in both the United Kingdom and the United States of America of a scheme of flammability labelling of certain furniture items in order to inform consumers of the level of flammability and the dangers inherent in the items they might be buying. However, to date the Government has not settled upon any firm solution of the problem. The Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs has already written to industry seeking its views, as well as to fire authorities, and safety and consumer organisations, to ascertain options which the Government could adopt to reduce the risk of injury caused by this particular problem. Labelling is the most obvious option. Other options involve the banning of particular materials such as polyurethane foam, and the examination of alternative methods of reducing flammability of low cost items. One concern that the Government has is that the banning of relatively cheap materials such as polyurethane foam obviously will raise the price through the use of alternative products.

I thank Senator McMullan for raising this question because the working group is meeting currently and submissions have been sought from interested parties and should be lodged by 31 March 1988. I therefore take this opportunity to remind people involved in the inquiry and the working group that they have until that date to make their concerns known to government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. The Minister will be aware that last week Dr Blewett announced a grant of $115,000 to the Hobart Women's Health Centre, to be used for research into why cardiovascular disease in Tasmanian women is increasing while the occurrence in men is declining. Is the Minister aware that the Hobart Women's Health Centre has premises but no staff? Is he also aware that the most recent national figures relating to the incidence of cardiovascular disease on a State by State basis, compiled by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in 1986, show that Tasmania has the highest reduction rate since 1984 for women with cardiovascular disease in all States except Queensland, and that overall Tasmania has the best improvement rate in Australia? I ask: Where is the evidence of an increasing incidence of cardiovascular disease among women in Tasmania? What are the qualifications and experience of the personnel conducting the research at the Hobart Women's Health Centre? In light of the fact that Dr Blewett gave such a large grant to a centre with no staff for research based on false information, what steps did the Government take to establish the bona fides of the application?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will do my best to answer all of the parts to the question that Senator Walters has posed for me. On 10 March Dr Blewett announced a national health promotion grant of $115,000-odd--
—Very odd dollars.

—That was to the Hobart Women's Health Centre for 18 months to develop a health promotion program on cardiovascular health for women. Senator Newman may say that it is odd, but I think it is an important issue. It will be disappointing for Tasmanians to hear that perhaps she does not think it is as important as that. The Hobart Women's Health Centre was established 12 months ago by the Hobart Women's Health Centre Group, which was set up in 1984. The Centre leases a building from which it carries out health education and counselling activities. It is run by three volunteer staff with experience and expertise in women's health. It has received no funding from the State Government and has operated from private donations and voluntary labour. The grant will enable it to expand its activities to benefit more Tasmanian women and to add to the knowledge of health promotion which effectively reaches women. Tasmania is one of the two States which do not have State funded women's health programs to meet local women's needs.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Walters asked me about the specific incidence of cardiovascular disease in women. The health promotion to prevent cardiovascular disease is an area of unmet need. Mortality rates for cardiovascular disease for Tasmanian women aged 45 to 59 years increased in the 10 years from 1973 to 1983, when they declined for the rest of Australia. Death rates have begun to decline recently, but the rate of decrease is lower than for men.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the Minister tell me why, when Dr Blewett was informed in Hobart that the Hobart Women's Health Centre did not have any staff and that the incidence of cardiovascular disease in women had decreased, he said that he would give the Hobart Women's Health Foundation the money until the Hobart Women's Health Centre was established and that his Department `might have been using last year's figures instead of this year's'? I can assure the Minister that Dr Blewett was not using last year's figures. Indeed, it was over six years ago that the increase in cardiovascular disease in women in Tasmania took place.

—I thank Senator Walters for her long, proselytising speech. Once again she has alleged a series of things, this time not even backed up, as at least an earlier question was backed up, by a reference to a Press report or some ascertainable quotation. Nothing she has said in her supplementary question contains any reference to any evidence at all that Dr Blewett said what she alleges he said. I will take Senator Walters's comments on notice and, if there is anything I think I need to add this week or next, I will add it.

—Is the Minister for Resources aware of a recent publication by the Australian Bureau for Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE)? Does this publication make predictions about the prospects for Australian mineral industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The prospect for the minerals sector in Australia is indeed very good. In fact, over the last 12 months it has recorded quite spectacular growth and, although gold has been a major engine of that growth, it is not entirely the case that the gross figures that have been returned relate to the strong performance of that commodity. I was pleased to be able to read the ABARE publication that came out today. Honourable senators may recall that the Australian Bureau for Agricultural and Resource Economics was formed after the last election when we created the Federal Department of Primary Industries and Energy and banded together the Bureau of Resource Economics and the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. The Australian Bureau for Agricultural and Resource Economics continues to maintain a very high standard in its research and publications, and the figures released in its publication today once again establish that fact beyond any question. I commend the Bureau for its very great work.

ANSWER.PARA: This morning, in opening the Bureau of Mineral Resources Petroleum and Minerals Review Conference, I was able to refer to the growth that has been rightly termed spectacular for Australia's minerals sector. Perhaps I can go to some of the detail for the Senate. The growth now accounts for almost 8 per cent of gross domestic product, with a mine output valued at over $22 billion. In 1987 the value of our mineral exports was over $16 billion, representing 43 per cent of total exports out of Australia. We expect that level of growth to continue. The ABARE report indicates that we expect a 3.4 per cent annual growth in the minerals sector between now and the year 2000. That growth will underpin our prosperity, help correct our current account deficit and provide tens of thousands of jobs for Australians all around the country.

Last year we set new records-this will be of interest to Senator Parer-for mine production in bauxite, black coal, brown coal, diamonds, iron ore and natural gas. Record smelter and refinery production levels were set for alumina, aluminium, copper, gold, lead bullion and zinc. These results are no accident. They reflect the industry's solid and sustained response to Government policies. In minerals, as in other fields, the Government has the settings right. It has provided an appropriate mix of incentives at the same time as ensuring that all Australians receive a fair return for the resources they own. Our record is already substantial, and the trends which I have outlined ensure that we will continue to build on our success in the years ahead.

One of the elements that will guarantee that we continue to build on our success is that under this Government we have embarked on a number of consultative arrangements with industry and have been able to attend to a far better industrial relations performance, particularly in this sector, than the previous Government was able to do. Indeed, last Thursday I had the privilege to attend a meeting of the Western Australian Iron Ore Industry Consultative Council, which is a joint Western Australian and Commonwealth body to bring unions, governments and employers together in the iron ore industry. It was reported by the companies at that meeting that contracts that they reached in the last round of contract negotiations with Japan, which guaranteed that Australia would return to be the most significant supplier to the Japanese market and regain the bigger share it had of the Japanese market, were due to the fact that productivity in the iron ore industry had increased by 40 per cent over the last three or four years.

Indeed, last October at the Australia-Japan iron ore conference at Scarborough Beach in Western Australia for the first time the Japanese never raised questions with iron ore producers about the reliability of supply because they were satisfied on that front; nor did they raise any questions about industrial relations in Australia. So, in terms of our ability to handle industrial relations in that industry, that has been a significant achievement during the life of this Government. It has enabled us to regain a major share of the Japanese iron ore industry and is indicative of our approach to this whole sector.
