TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 February 1988 Senator Sanders asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, a question about Coronation Hill. I have obtained an answer. It is reasonably lengthy so I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

Mineral lease 19 is located at Coronation Hill within the Kakadu Conservation Zone. It was originally granted under the Northern Territory Mining Ordinance on 22 July 1947 for the purpose of mining for silver and lead. Under the Ordinance a lessee could explore for any mineral on his lease but could only mine for those minerals specified in the lease. However, at any time he could apply to have additional minerals specified in his lease. The holders of ML 19 did apply, in 1955, to have the lease varied to include copper and uranium.

Notwithstanding this history BHP Gold Mines Ltd, the current holders of ML 19, have applied to the Commonwealth to develop a gold, platinum and palladium mine at Coronation Hill. It is for the purpose of assessing the gold, platinum and palladium mine proposal that BHP has been requested to complete an environmental impact statement.

On 16 February the Minister for Administrative Services advised the House that he intended to issue BHP with an access authority to remove any doubt surrounding BHP's rights to continue exploration activities presently being undertaken at Coronation Hill. Since then, he has issued two authorities covering the operations of BHP Gold Mines Ltd at Coronation Hill. One authority will allow exploration work to continue on the pre-existing mineral lease areas including ML 19. The other will permit access to those parts of the Conservation Zone outside the leases so that work can be undertaken in preparation of an environmental impact statement. This work is required for the Government's consideration of any future mining plans for Coronation Hill.

The exploration authority will be managed on behalf of the Commonwealth by the Northern Territory Director of Mines in consultation with both the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service and the Office of the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region. It specifically excludes the right to explore for uranium. The access authority permitting work outside the pre-existing leases in preparation of the environmental impact statement will be managed by the Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service. Both authorities are subject to stringent environmental conditions which have been recommended by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. The authorities can be varied at any time and they can also be terminated if the conditions are not met. Furthermore the exploration authority for the pre-existing mineral leases now provides environmental conditions over the operation which previously did not exist. This is a greatly improved situation.
