SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Macklin moving forthwith a motion of which he gave notice earlier this day.

I believe that this is a matter of urgency. Monday was the last day available for clemency to be provided without an executive order to the six blacks who were condemned to death for a crime that was committed 3 1/2 years ago. The information became available yesterday; I moved the motion today. However, the problem is that the sentences are due to be carried out on Friday this week. I do believe it is a matter of urgency. At this point I do not want to canvass the substance of the issue, as I understand that both the Government and the Opposition believe it is a matter of urgency. Of course, this does not necessarily mean that they will support the motion. I think they have recognised that the matter is urgent. It is a matter of international concern. It is of concern both to our Government and the governments of Britain, where there has been a debate in the House of Commons; the United States, where there has been a great deal of publicity and indeed appeals from the highest level; West Germany, and most European countries. In fact, most countries around the world have issued appeals for clemency to the South African Government.

It is important that these issues be debated in this chamber today and that we do what we can to add our weight to the international campaign to persuade the Government in Pretoria that the course on which it has embarked is not only likely to lead to the deaths of possibly six innocent people but also will vastly exacerbate the situation in South Africa, due to the fact that the executions to be carried out this Friday will be carried out three days short of the anniversary of the Sharpeville massacre. We are dealing with people from the same area and riots which occurred in the same area. We must be mindful that we are looking at the possibility of more deaths surrounding this whole incident. Therefore, I urge the Senate to accept the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders, as I understand it will, so we can debate the motion clearly and directly.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not oppose the suspension of Standing Orders to deal with this matter. As Senator Macklin had indicated, it is a matter, I would hope, of worldwide community concern. We do not want to debate the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders, although we may have some differences as to the substantive motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition agrees that there should be a debate on the substantive motion. As it happens, the Government and the Opposition are likely to take a similar view on the substantive motion. However, we appear to be of one agreement that we should not waste the Senate's time having a footling debate about whether or not to suspend Standing Orders but should move to the consideration of the substantive motion.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-

(a) condemns the South African Government for its decision to go ahead with the hanging of six black South Africans for the murder of a black municipal councillor despite the fact that the Appeals Court has accepted that there is no proof that the six had contributed to the councillor's death;
(b) further condemns the South African Government for ignoring appeals for clemency from Australia's Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, and from countries such as Britain and the United States; and

(c) calls on the Australian Government to withdraw visas to the 100 South African gold experts as a practical demonstration of Australia's opposition to the apartheid system which allows this obscenity.

The Australian Democrats decided to move the motion today because it is a matter of great urgency. It concerns six people who, while they have not been proven to be guilty of murder, will be hanged on Friday of this week for the murder of a black South African councillor. We believe that the fate of those six people depends on the actions that may be taken around the world to bring home to the South African Government that it is not only its system but also the operation of the justice system in that country that will not and cannot be tolerated by the world at large. There cannot be a more important issue for us to attempt to influence than this one this week. Late last night the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden, pleaded with the South African Government to commute the death sentences imposed on the five men and one woman who are to be executed. The Australian Ambassador to South Africa has also made an urgent appeal to South Africa on this matter. Today the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions Congress called on the heads of government to make urgent representations to South Africa to prevent the hangings. As I said in the debate on the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders, there have been direct appeals from governments around the world-in fact, from all governments representing the type of society in which we live-which we believe are governed by the rule of law and which seek to provide justice.

The facts of the case are these: six black South Africans aged between 22 and 32 years are due to be hanged this week-three days short of the twenty-eighth anniversary of the Sharpeville massacre on 21 March 1960 when South African police opened fire on a crowd protesting against apartheid laws and 69 people were killed. Those six people have been known in the campaign that has been running internationally as the `Sharpeville Six'. They were found guilty of the murder of a black Sharpeville municipal councillor as a result of his quite gruesome mob killing in September 1984. I would not want it to be taken from anything that I or other honourable senators may say in this debate that we condone in any way that very gruesome murder of a black councillor.

At the time of the murder, the black townships had erupted in protest at rent increases imposed by black-run councils of the various areas. The councils had come to be seen by a very large number of blacks in the townships as mere agents for the Government in Pretoria. Men, such as the victim about whom we are talking, Mr Dlamini, were branded as sell-outs and the penalty for collaboration was deemed to be death. After hearing evidence in the case, the trial judge-it is a very salutary lesson to read through some of the extremely flimsy evidence that was offered regarding a number of these people-adopted the previously innocuous legal doctrine of guilt through common purpose. The appeal judge also accepted there was no proof that the six had causally contributed to Mr Dlamini's death. He ruled that they shared a common purpose with a mob intent on murder. Therefore, they were deemed to be accessories to the crime and were sentenced to hang. As I have said, the verdicts were upheld on appeal. Page 83 of the appeal court judgment states:

In the case of these accused it is perhaps debatable whether a causal connection between the conduct of each, individually, and the death of the deceased, had indeed not been proved, but in the case of others it must be accepted without doubt, in my opinion, that no such causal connection can be found to have been proved . . . I shall therefore assume that for the purposes of my judgement that it has not been proved in the case of any six accused convicted of murder that their conduct had contributed (as a cause) to the death of the deceased.
I will read that again because I think it is extraordinary, when six people are to be hanged this Friday, that the appeal court judge could say:

I shall therefore assume that for the purposes of my judgement that it has not been proved in the case of any six accused convicted of murder that their conduct had contributed (as a cause) to the death of the deceased.
Later in the appeal court judgment the judge said:
In the present case I am dealing with the position of the six accused who have been convicted of murder solely on the basis of common purpose.

I think that those facts are clear and undisputed. As has been said on a number of occasions in the international campaign that has been running on this issue, if there were a case for clemency in those countries which have capital punishment, surely this must be one. Unfortunately, all avenues within the South African political and legal system have now been exhausted. Only a presidential reprieve can save the accused. It has been indicated, not formally but at least informally, that President Botha has absolutely no intention of offering clemency in this case.

If one looks at the current situation in South Africa one will see fairly clearly why this is so. The reason has nothing to do with the case. It has nothing to do with six people declared by the appeal judge to be innocent of the murder of the person concerned. It has a lot to do with the apartheid system and the political situation in South Africa today. First of all, township elections are due later this year. Obviously President Botha wants to make an example of the Sharpeville six as a means of protecting black councillors and reducing further the street protests and associated violence.

Secondly, the pressure from the right wing parties, the Afrikaner parties, in South Africa has been obvious in this particular case. One only has to refer to some of the statements made at meetings around the country, particularly those by the right wing political parties, to know that the majority party is under great pressure from the extreme right in South Africa. Any failure of will, as it will be seen by these right wing parties, in the granting of clemency in this particular case will be seen merely as the Government going weak on the exercise. To be tough now means no clemency. To be tough now offers the opportunity of further votes and seats. I think that it is fairly clear that these people's lives are simply being gambled for votes and seats in South Africa at the local elections coming up shortly-if not at subsequent by-elections and Federal elections.

The pressure that has been brought to bear on South Africa up to now has been to no avail. The pressure that our Government, in linking with other governments, has sought to bring to bear has also been to no avail. The legal processes that were used to determined the guilt of the Sharpeville six have far-reaching implications which surely must be abhorrent to all Australians who seek to protect the rights of individuals. In our legal system it is assured that any accused are innocent until proven guilty, regardless of colour, race or creed. One has to ask what the legal implications are if the hangings go ahead. Prior to the media clampdown Australian audiences watching the news would have seen many crowds, sometimes numbering in the thousands, and incidents resulting in some gruesome deaths. Surely if this judgment is upheld, all members of such crowds could be declared guilty. The legal ramifications alone are enormous. The possibilities for repression in those circumstances are horrendous.

I believe that we have to ask what our relationship is to the Government of South Africa, which promotes, supports and attempts to proselytise others to the advantages of the apartheid system. I believe that the Australian Government has shown amazing inconsistency in respect of its policy on South Africa. It really is a `now you see me, now you don't' policy which reeks of double standards. I ask honourable senators to remember the episode of the rebel cricketers when they visited South Africa in 1985-86 and the threat of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to have their tax returns scrutinised. Later there was the highly personal attack on leading cricketers, particularly Kim Hughes. Honourable senators will remember the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade talking about blood money. However, at this moment we are awaiting calls from Mr Hayden and the Australian Government for clemency for the Sharpeville six who, undoubtedly, are direct victims of the apartheid system.

I remind honourable senators also of the simultaneous decision to grant visas for experts from the South African gold industry so that they can visit Australia. I asked a question of Senator Button about this yesterday. At that time he defended that decision to grant visas to allow these experts to attend a conference. He said:
. . . given South Africa's position as the world's major gold producer, the Government accepts that representation from that country is desirable and appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read it in context, will you. You had alleged that they were businessmen and I just made the point that they were geologists.
—As Senator Button objects, I will read the entire answer. He stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macklin asked me a question today about participation by South Africans at a bicentennial gold conference in Melbourne on 18 to 20 May. As I recall Senator Macklin's question, it was suggested that a large number of South Africans will participate, and that most of the participants are executives of gold mining companies. I am advised-and at this stage I am giving limited information only-that the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs is aware of about 50 applications from South African mining experts, mostly academics and technical experts, to participate in the conference. All of these applications are being considered on a case by case basis in accordance with the Australian Government's policy of limiting official and other contact with South Africa. However, given South Africa's position as the world's major gold producer, the Government accepts that representation from that country is desirable and appropriate.

Would it not, in fact, be more desirable and appropriate at this time to stand up to the South African Government's actions and make a concerted effort, by whatever means we can, to have those six people saved from the gallows on Friday? I urge the Government to withdraw the visas immediately-as I have requested in my motion-to demonstrate quite directly that on this occasion and in regard to this issue we will make a further retaliation over and above other actions already taken by the Government, for example, in regard to Qantas flights. I urge that we take a particular action linked to a particular event. This would show the South African Government that such matters are of enormous concern to all people in Australia and that we do not want visits from South African people. We should demonstrate that we do not intend to go through the channels of government to government recognition of people by offering visas to those who apply for them but that we will not allow them to come to our country either at this time or next week when this particular action has taken place. Such a concrete proposal as I have suggested in my motion would be a direct action in regard to this issue. In the past the Government has singled out certain groups for sanctions. We are now asking the Government to single out another group for sanctions. In the past Australian sportsmen have been singled out. We are asking that white South African gold industry executives be singled out for sanction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not executives. You keep saying that. That is a very comforting word to you, is it not?

—All right, the white elite in the gold industry then-the geologists, the technical experts. I am quite sure that none of them is short of a quid. I am sure that none of them lives in the types of conditions in which the blacks in South Africa live. Regardless of the standing of white Australian cricketers, we were happy to seek some types of sanctions against them. Regardless of the standing of these white South African mining experts and technicians, why are we not willing to seek some sanctions against them? We are seeking a specific sanction for a specific purpose. We are asking for sanctions with regard to this particular item because of the importance of the gold industry to the South African economy, the obvious importance of those people who are coming here and the importance of the conference to the South African economy.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not seeking sanctions against people who are looking at the marble industry, as some people have done in recent times. We are not asking for sanctions against rope manufacturers who have come here in recent times. We are asking for these sanctions now because this is occurring now. We are asking for them now also because these people are connected with the gold industry which is so pertinent to the industrial health of South Africa. This is a very pertinent group of people against whom we can show our displeasure and the displeasure of the Australian community. I do not believe that the Government should fear in any way hurting the feelings of anybody in South Africa or upsetting anybody in South Africa. If the Government does hold such fears, it should weigh them against the feelings and concerns of the families of the people who are about to be hanged.

We in this place allot a lot of time to the discussion of all sort of matters. Indeed, we allotted a great deal of time this morning to the discussion of the feelings of someone who had been affronted by words said about him and the possible legal action that could have arisen out of that. We spent an enormous amount of time discussing that matter because that person is a citizen of Australia. It is to our credit that we are willing to spend time on those issues in an effort to uphold individual rights in this country. As a community, as a parliament, as a chamber, we have to make some type of response to such situations-not just words; we need to take some type of action.

If the Government and the Opposition are not willing to accept the third part of my motion, which deals with the type of action that should be taken, I plead with them to suggest some appropriate, concrete action that we as a parliament, incorporating all of the political parties, can vote on and endorse. We do not need just more words. Knowing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, I am quite sure that he has used his eloquence in this situation. I am not saying that in any cynical way. I am quite sure that he has done so because I know the type of person he is. He would be feeling very deeply and very personally about this matter. He has done all that he can. I am now urging that we do more and that we take some concrete action.

Although I have not consulted my colleagues about this, I am sure that they would be quite willing to support any amendment to my motion which substituted some other concrete action upon which all of the parties in this chamber could agree. I urge the Government and the Opposition to come up with a proposal. Let us not, at the end of this debate, delete the last paragraph of my motion and merely add more words, because more words are not what is needed at this time. More words, in addition to those that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade or anybody else has put forward, will not save those six people from being hanged on Friday. Let us try to come up with some concrete proposal that may put more pressure on the South African Government. Unfortunately, the likelihood is that we will not be successful; but let us not say that we have not tried to actually save those six lives that are now at stake in South Africa as a result of the abominable apartheid system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will support paragraphs (a) and (b) of Senator Macklin's motion but not paragraph (c). That is to say, we will be doing what he asked us a minute ago not to do. I want to explain why we will be doing that. I will be asking for the motion to be divided into the three separate paragraphs when the question is put. Nobody has a monopoly on concern about the proposed hanging of six blacks in connection with an incident at Sharpeville. I personally am against capital punishment wherever it occurs. I am particularly against it when it happens to be in respect of an alleged offence which is, I believe, unknown to a proper system of justice. I am particularly against it in the political and racial context of South Africa.

SPEECH.PARA: I share Senator Macklin's view that the proposed hanging is for political reasons of the most unworthy kind. I do not want to add to what Senator Macklin has said about those matters, except to say that one very much shares that concern. I suppose that where we differ is that Senator Macklin says, `Let us stand up and stop the hangings'. The sad fact is that we can stand up here and pass any motion we like but we will not stop the hangings if the South African Government has made up its mind about this issue. Senator Macklin warned us against using more words. I share his concern about the lack of efficacy of words in a situation such as this. That same comment applies to the third paragraph of his motion as he applied it to us: it is just a question of not using more words.

I come now to why we differ from Senator Macklin on this issue. I want to get on the record a number of statements about the Australian Government's attitude to this question and actions which have been specifically taken by the Australian Government. The Australian Government first made representations to the South African Government on 11 December 1987, calling for clemency for the six defendants on humanitarian grounds, expressing concern at the severity of the sentences and stressing that an act of clemency by the State President would be interpreted as a gesture of good will and could make an important contribution to internal stability in South Africa.

Numerous appeals for clemency have included one made on 1 February by the meeting in Lusaka of the Commonwealth Committee of Foreign Ministers on Southern Africa, of which Mr Hayden is a member. Those expressions of concern made in December last year and February this year-the second by Commonwealth Foreign Ministers-have apparently had no effect on the South African Government, because the decision to proceed with the hangings has been announced since that time. The Foreign Ministers expressed distress at the imposition of death sentences even though it had not been proved that any of the six contributed causally to the death of the deceased. The Foreign Ministers said that the executions, if proceeded with, would only increase bitterness at a time when the need for breaking South Africa's cycle of violence was paramount. Thirdly, they said that it would be a setback for all who were working to bring about a peaceful resolution of South Africa's problems. Even at this stage, on 16 March, the Government hopes that there will be some recognition of that appeal.

On 15 March Mr Hayden made the appeal to which Senator Macklin refers in his motion, asking that the death sentence be commuted and again reiterating the views which he had put on 11 December and which were put by the Committee of Foreign Ministers in February. Mr Hayden made the point that Australia was strongly opposed in principle to the death penalty but he said in this case it was particularly unacceptable. None of the six had been directly involved in the murder with which they had been charged. He went on to make some points about the likely exacerbation of a volatile political environment if these death sentences were to be proceeded with. Again, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) made the point that this would only convince some South Africans that peaceful change was no longer a realistic possibility in that country.

Subsequently, the Australian Ambassador also made representations to the South African Government. There are some who follow the logic, if we can call it that-the way out logic if they expressed it further than Senator Macklin's argument-that in order to put pressure on South Africa we should have no ambassador there at all, and who might express that view. It is not something which the Australian Government agrees with.

I suppose that the departure point from the motion which Senator Macklin has moved and which we and the Opposition readily acceded to being brought on, for the reason that we share the concern, is as to what we should do about the essential policy issue in connection with South Africa. I just want to make it clear that the Australian Government, in concert with other governments-that is to say, on agreed rules-has imposed a general policy of not issuing visitor visas in South Africa to South African citizens, residents or visitors. Senator Macklin's motion refers to the 100 South African gold experts who are likely to come to this conference later this year. The Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs has no real idea, but it estimates that it is probably fewer than 50. I am not making a point about this--

TALK.START.PARA: —They said that up to 100 would be all right.

—I said that the Department has no idea because people from all over the world apply for visas to come to events such as this. The Australian Government's policy is one of not issuing visas except in certain circumstances. That policy, together with other governments' policies, is an expression of our concern about apartheid. It is designed not to frustrate the needs of South African individuals but only to inconvenience them. They are treated quite separately from citizens of other countries. To go further than that, it might be seen as requiring visitors policy to reflect a number of international issues of concern to the government of the day. For example, we could have a different visitors policy in respect of Russian citizens because of Russia's involvement in Afghanistan. We could have a different visa policy for Cubans because of Cuba's involvement in Angola. We could have a different visitors policy for citizens of the United States of America because of the United States Government's mining of a port in Nicaragua. We could have a different visa policy for Chilean visitors for a variety of reasons. We could have a different visa policy for the Chinese because of actions taken in Tibet, or for Vietnamese in respect of actions taken in Kampuchea. That might seem attractive to Senator Powell, who I think interjected, `Hear, hear!', but it is not a matter which any government could contemplate seriously. It is not a matter which could be contemplated by any serious government. More than that, it is far from clear that penalising individuals for foreign affairs policy purposes is a sound and equitable approach because of the sorts of examples to which I have just referred.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me return to the nub of the matter. There is a very sad and tragic situation in South Africa which is about to be made worse by these proposed hangings. That is a matter of great concern and about which I understand the Democrats' motion. The next step is to say, `We will make a gesture about that. We have an issue here. We will capitalise on that concern by saying that the Australian Government should give a knee-jerk reaction and say that, at a conference to take place in August, no South Africans will be permitted to attend'. I think that is wrong in terms of policy; I think it is wrong because it is knee-jerk; and it is wrong because it will have absolutely no effect. It may well damage our standing as a country in terms of consistent policy making and consistent guidelines about these issues with which we are in agreement with other countries, and that is most important.

Senator Macklin attacked this Government for, as he puts it, its hypocrisy, and other governments for their hypocrisy, in relation to South Africa. But let me say one thing which I am sure he will recognise. This Government is not particularly admired and its predecessor was not particularly admired by the ruling South African Government because of the stance which we have taken and which the Fraser Government took on a variety of issues. We have not been particularly admired in South Africa and that is something of which I am intensely proud and of which I am sure Senator Chaney, as Leader of the Opposition, is also proud. But to get into this position of auctioning issues, trying to solve a very serious problem like this with a solution which is a knee-jerk, which I believe will produce no effect and will be a demonstrable stunt response, is no solution at all.

As I said earlier, this Senate cannot go too far in its condemnation of the death penalty in a situation like this; in its condemnation of apartheid in South Africa and these sorts of consequences of apartheid. It cannot go too far in its condemnation of extraordinary offences, such as the offence with which these people have been charged. It cannot go too far in any of those things. But to play politics and link that up with the proposed conference in Melbourne at which possibly 50 out of 1,000 delegates will come from South Africa, and to say, `We will punish these people and, therefore, perhaps produce a result in South Africa', is kidding ourselves and not making a contribution to a very important and serious policy debate. It is for that reason that we will not vote for and support the third proposition in Senator Macklin's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to this motion on behalf of the Opposition, though again, like the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button), not at great length because there is a high degree of common ground on the matters which are raised, although on this occasion the Opposition is of the same view as the Government with respect to opposing the third paragraph of the motion moved by Senator Macklin today. The motion is in two clear parts. The first two paragraphs state:

SPEECH.PARA: (a) condemn the South African Government for its decision to go ahead with the hanging of six black South Africans for the murder of a black municipal councillor despite the fact that the Appeals Court has accepted that there is no proof that the six had contributed to the councillor's death;
(b) further condemns the South African Government for ignoring appeals for clemency from Australia's Foreign Minister, Mr Hayden, and from countries such as Britain and the United States;

It is on those paragraphs that there is common ground between the Government, the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. I think the facts relating to that matter have been sufficiently outlined by Senator Macklin, who has referred the Senate to the elements of the judgment of the Appeals Court. The circumstances are such that I believe most Australians would be thoroughly disturbed by the proposition that these people are to be hanged. I suppose on the other hand it is unusual that a national parliament should debate the criminal law processes of another government. The reality is that there is a plethora of countries around the world which have systems of criminal law and government which are utterly repugnant to us. If I may make a personal comment, my only reservation about the unanimity with which we are approaching these elements of the motion is that I believe that many South Africans feel, understandably, that horrific acts occur in other parts of the world, including other parts of Africa, that do not receive the same condemnation. I simply mark that because I do believe that one element of the debate which needs continuous re-examination is the question of consistency.

It has always been a personal view of mine that we are prepared to condemn South Africa, very properly, for a regime that is unique because of its institutionalised racism. However, pretty horrifying action that occurs in other areas escapes general scrutiny. I mention that because I think it does disturb many Australians that there appears to them to be a lack of concern about other equally abhorrent elements.

It is worth stressing in this debate that the condemnation of apartheid in South Africa is a long-standing matter that has crossed party lines. It has flowed through the whole of the period of the present Opposition. I refer the Senate to the lengthy statement made by the then Leader of the Opposition on 19 August 1985, which sets out in some detail the general approach which the Opposition has. That statement has been reaffirmed over recent years. It reads:

The central issue in South African affairs is how to achieve radical reform with the minimum of violence and disruption within the South African community. The reforms required are essentially two: the abolition of apartheid and equal treatment before the law of all South Africans, and power sharing among all members of the South African community.

I simply reaffirm the concerns which have been continually expressed by the Opposition, as were expressed when it formed the Government of this country. I share the very deep reservations which have been expressed in this chamber and elsewhere about the procedures that have led to half a dozen people facing death by execution in circumstances where it appears quite clear that they were not directly involved in the murder for which they were tried.

Where then is the area of difference? The difference is one that has at times existed between the Government and the Opposition, rather than between the Opposition, the Government and the Australian Democrats, as applies today. When we defined our position in 1985-and I stress that this position has been reaffirmed-we said:

It is against the achievement of the objective of abolishing apartheid that the effects of the imposition of economic sanctions must be judged. The coalition believes that the hard truth is that sanctions are counterproductive and will not bring about the abolition of apartheid.

Instead of encouraging the South African Government to implement reforms, the application of sanctions is all too likely to have precisely the opposite effect. The more conservative elements in South Africa will be reinforced in their opposition to reform. Sanctions are likely to become the external enemy, against which the South African Government and the white community, feeling increasingly isolated, will unite.
Later in the statement the Opposition said:

The coalition does not take the view that in no circumstances should economic sanctions be imposed. Sanctions have a role in international affairs and the coalition does not exclude in advance of events, their use, whether against South Africa or any other country. It should be noted that the coalition has supported a trade embargo on arms sales to South Africa. It is pointless, however, to speculate about the circumstances in which economic sanctions might be imposed against a country, and unwise to make a commitment in advance of events. It is far better to make judgments on the facts of the day rather than on possibilities of the future.

In light of that statement I think we have to confront the proposition which the Australian Democrats have put before us today, which is that we should support the third paragraph of the motion, which calls on the Australian Government to withdraw visas to the 100 South African gold experts as a practical demonstration of Australia's opposition to the apartheid system which allows this obscenity. The position of the Opposition is that we do not believe that paragraph should be supported. Like the Government, we do not see it as something that will be effective.

It may be little more than words-and Senator Macklin has asked the Opposition to do more than advocate additional words-but I think the view which Senator Macklin has, that words alone will not be efficacious, is in fact no different from our view that this gesture-which will simply deny Australia the participation of the South African gold experts in the Australian intellectual life and, to some extent, the economy-would not in any sense be an effective strike against South Africa. It seems to me to be rather more a strike against Australia than against South Africa. Therefore, it seems to have the same problem of being a token gesture.

Certainly that would be some action, but though it might well increase the degree of resentment which is felt, it is unlikely to put any real pressure on the South African Government. For that reason in my view the proposition which has been put by the Australian Democrats in the third paragraph should not be supported.

I have handed to the Clerk an amendment which would have the simple effect of deleting paragraph (c) from the motion. If it transpires that the motion is dealt with in paragraphs, the Opposition will be happy with that procedure and will vote against that paragraph. To avoid any slippage in the proceedings, I formally move at this stage for the deletion of paragraph (c) on the basis that we will vote accordingly if the matter comes to a vote on the motion as a whole.

The only other thing I wish to say in this debate is that the fact that the Government declines to support paragraph (c) of the Australian Democrats' motion, namely the withdrawal of visas to visiting experts, is a factor that should be remembered in future debates. I for one am sick of the proposition that any failure to support sanctions, either in general or in particular, represents a statement that one is in some way soft on apartheid or is in favour of apartheid, or is opposed to any real reform in South Africa. That is certainly not the view of the Opposition. The selective approach that we have adopted is one based on our belief as to what is best or most likely to achieve results in South Africa; that is, results that will move South Africa towards being a more liberal society, one in which there is more rather than less genuine power sharing. The Opposition has never taken the view that the substitution of one non-democratic form of government for another could in any sense be regarded as a significant advance.

The simple point I make is that on this occasion the Government is itself displaying selectivity. I simply remind Government senators of that fact. Far too often in discussion on these matters cheap debating points are made which do not reflect the genuine concerns felt within the Opposition, and do not reflect the genuine motivation of the Opposition for the stance it has taken. The fact is that this Government is selective. Indeed, we would see the Government's actions in providing approximately $100m of aid in circumstances which are well known in Africa, and its comparative neglect of some areas of greater local concern to us, as not being in Australia's best interests and not showing a proper appreciation of the priorities that we believe should be accorded in Australia's foreign aid.

The Government has often adopted positions which smack of a degree of consistency which they have not in fact had. I think its preparedness to oppose the proposal of the Australian Democrats today is a simple reminder that the situation is rather more complex than the debate that takes place here and elsewhere sometimes admits. I therefore support the condemnation of the South African Government over the hanging of the six black South Africans for the murder of a black municipal councillor, despite the fact that the appeals court has accepted that there is no proof that the six contributed to the councillor's death. For the reasons I have indicated and for the reasons which were broadly expressed by the Leader of the Government in the Senate I indicate that we also will oppose the third leg of the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion moved by Senator Macklin for the Australian Democrats, which calls on the Senate to condemn the South African Government over the planned execution this Friday, 18 March-two days away-of six black Africans who are known as the Sharpeville six and who have been referred to during this debate as six black South Africans and in various other ways but who, I remind the Senate, are six human beings. Those people have names, and I would like to put them on the record. They are young black South Africans by the names of Duma Joshua Khumalo, aged 26; Mojulefa Reginald Sefatsa, aged 30; Reid Malebo Mokoena, aged 22; Theresa Ramashaemola, aged 24, who on Friday will become the first South African woman to be executed; Oupa Moses Diniso, aged 30; and Francis Don Mokhesi, aged 29. They are South African human beings to be executed on Friday.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that anyone in this chamber, in all honesty, could not but support the moral issue here. That not one of the numerous courts of law that have heard this case has found that any one of the six actually committed the crime of which they have been accused and for which they will be executed on Friday-that these six young black South Africans are to be hanged in two days time in such circumstances-is a matter of great seriousness, and I believe that all in this chamber should support this motion.

A further part of the motion calls on the Australian Government to withdraw visas for white South African goldmining representatives planning to visit Melbourne in May to participate in the international conference Bicentennial Gold 88, a conference to be hosted by the Victorian Department of Industry, Technology and Resources and which is now only some eight weeks away. Given the Australian Labor Party's undertaking in its 1986 platform to `base its policy (on South Africa) on the isolation of the apartheid regime' and to `refuse entry or transit to South African sporting teams and individual amateur and professional sports players representing South Africa', I believe that the inhuman behaviour of the South African Government in the case of these six young black South Africans demands that the Australian Government do all that it can to make its outrage and the outrage of the Australian community known to the South African Government. One immediate way of doing this is to refuse visas to these South African goldmining representatives. I will have a little more to say about the response which we have heard so far in this debate to that part of Senator Macklin's motion.

The Australian Democrats applaud the recent and last minute direct pleas for clemency by the British and the United States governments as well as those by Australia's Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Bill Hayden, and Australia's Ambassador to South Africa, Mr Birch. The case of the Sharpeville six has been recognised and taken up by other Western democracies, and many voices around the world have been raised. Even within South Africa, not surprisingly, Helen Suzman, the veteran white anti-apartheid campaigner, called on the Government to grant a reprieve. She and Colin Elgin, leader of the white liberal Progressive Federal Party were instrumental in having a meeting last week, which was unsuccessful from the point of view of any clemency. We should know, too, that the delegates of the 97 countries attending the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions (ICFTU) congress being held right now in Melbourne have also called on heads of government to make urgent representations to South Africa in an attempt to prevent the hangings. The ICFTU represents 87 million trade unionists around the world.

A further reason for Australia to take the strongest possible action in condemning South Africa follows the recent very harsh actions taken by the racist South African Government to ban the nation's 17 known anti-apartheid groups from engaging in any political activity. These are a broad range of groups which include, for example, the Detainees Parents Support Committee. That banning action has been one of the more outrageous recent actions. Other groups to be covered by that ban are the Soweto Civic Association, which represents people in the country's largest black township and is behind the long- running rent boycott there, the Release Mandela Committee and other such committees, and the Congress of South African Trade Unions.

That ban was followed by action by the church leaders in South Africa. We read in the Age of 2 March of the march which was led by church leaders, of the arrest of Bishop Tutu when he lead about 150 churchmen, who were stopped by police, `protesting at the . . . curbs on the anti-apartheid opposition groups'. Archbishop Tutu said that the clergymen represented about 12 million South Africans and that they were not the usual rabble rousers like himself and Dr Alan Boesak, President of the World Alliance of Reformed Churches and leader of the coloured branch of the Dutch Reformed Church. He said that a whole range of church leaders had now got behind those two front-runners and that opposition was building within South Africa to the highly repressive actions that the bannings represented. So, as has already been pointed out in this debate, the situation continues to get worse. Dr Alan Boesak himself has said of South Africa:
What we are facing now is a situation in which every single action we can take has been criminalized.

How dreadful it must be to be living in that kind of environment-something which it is probably very difficult for Australians, in our very free and open democracy, to understand. This most recent decision is quite clearly outrageous. We have read editorials all around this country condemning it, including editorials in the Canberra Times of 28 February and the Sydney Morning Herald of 26 February, part of which I think bears repeating. This banning of the remaining 17 anti-apartheid organisations, as the Sydney Morning Herald puts it, `will intensify racial conflict in South Africa and provoke further violence between the Government and its opponents'. Sometimes it is very difficult to understand the motivation behind all this.

The comment was made earlier in the debate, I think by Senator Button, that calls have been made for increased pressure. I point out that the Australian Council for Overseas Aid (ACFOA), in its response to the bannings, called on the Federal Government immediately to downgrade the diplomatic mission in South Africa by recalling the Ambassador. ACFOA says that it believes that we know what is happening in South Africa, that we do not need an ambassador to listen to the cries of the black majority for democracy and freedom. Further, it says that what we need is renewed international effort to end apartheid and that Australia should maintain its strong stand against apartheid by applying this diplomatic sanction. One of the things that the Democrats are trying to do in moving this motion, particularly paragraph (c) of the motion, is to have some action taken, to have something concrete done, other than simple condemnation. To that extent, we line up with ACFOA, which has also made its call for some specific action.

Returning to the specific issue of the planned execution of the six young black South Africans, I note, as Senator Macklin did in his contribution, that it is pointed out on page 83 of the court judgment that the executions will take place in spite of the fact that-and it is worth quoting again-the judge said:
. . . for the purposes of my judgment . . . it has not been proved in the case of any six accused convicted of murder that their conduct had contributed (as a cause) to the death of the deceased.

I think that is what we really must remember. It is almost impossible to believe in this world in which we live that six people will die in 1988 even though the judge concerned has said that they do not have any direct responsibility for the crime of which they have been accused.

This doctrine of common purpose, as it has been defined, is absolutely abhorrent. The Australian Democrats believe that some action must be taken. A good deal has already been said in this debate about that doctrine. I would simply like to place on record my abhorrence to it. As has been pointed out in the Canberra Times, critics of the judgment have said there are far-reaching implications. It is horrific to think that, if a man is killed in a confrontation involving a crown 1,000 strong, any or all of those present might be found guilty of murder and be hanged.

As I said, the Australian Democrats are calling for action, not just for words. I would have to object to Senator Button's accusation that what we are doing here is calling for some sort of knee-jerk reaction. When our attention was drawn to the fact that a substantial group of South African delegates were expected to attend a conference in Victoria, we investigated the situation. Right at the beginning of this month-some two weeks ago-we called for visas to be refused. This is not something that we dreamed up this morning or even this week. It is an issue that we took up once it was drawn to our attention. We are merely reiterating, by way of Senator Macklin's motion, the call that Senator Haines made on 3 March for the Government to refuse visas to this group of South African delegates who want to attend the conference in Victoria.

I would like to say a little more about this proposal. This conference, which will take place in Melbourne in May, some eight weeks away, is a bicentennial event. This year we are celebrating our 200 years as a nation. I, for one, would not want to be celebrating with people from South Africa in the knowledge of the sort of thing that we have been talking about in this debate. As a Victorian, I find it quite abhorrent that the documentation for this conference includes a specific invitation issued by the Victorian Minister for Industry, Technology and Resources, an invitation which continues to apply to South African delegates to this conference.

I believe that it is pertinent that the conference is concerned with the gold industry. This is a significant opportunity for us to take some action which would clearly signify our abhorrence of the apartheid system. The gold industry is one of the major industries in South Africa and we can have some impact on it if we can affect it in any way. Of course, the gold mining industry is one of the exploitative industries of South Africa. We know that the history of South Africa is one of exploitation, not just of resources but also of black human beings. It is a history of disgrace. I think this in itself is a further reason why the action we are proposing would be far more than simply symbolic. This action would make very many statements about how we feel about links with South Africa, about any kind of succour or support which might be gained or be characterised as having come from this country, whether or not that is our intention.

I think we need to be aware that we are not in control of the way in which actions taken or not taken by our country or any other country outside South Africa are portrayed within South Africa. There are enough anecdotes available to demonstrate that quite often there is distortion by South African citizens of the sort of support that exists in the rest of the world for South Africa.

As a resident of Victoria, and as a Victorian parliamentarian in this Senate, I make my own call to Minister Fordham and, indeed, to the Premier of Victoria, specifically to withdraw the invitation to any South African delegates in the light of all of the points which I have already made in this debate since it is obvious that their Federal colleagues are not prepared to make it impossible for those delegates to attend that conference.

I would like to pick up a few of the points that have been made in the debate, particularly those put forward by Senator Button. The honourable senator said that nobody has a monopoly of concern, not wanting anybody to believe that the Government does not feel as strongly as the Australian Democrats do in spite of the fact that the Government will not support this motion in its entirety. Senator Button is quite correct; the Australian Democrats do not claim a monopoly of concern. But there is one area in which the Government, and Senator Button, as the Leader of the Government in this chamber, do have a monopoly: they have the power to act. That is one of the reasons for the Democrats' motion, which calls upon the Government to act and to take a specific action-that is, to withdraw the visas for a significant group of South African delegates to a significant international conference under our bicentennial banner in the State of Victoria.

Senator Button says that we should not punish people for the actions of government. But we, of all people, must never forget that governments and parliaments are made up of people who represent the rest of the population. There is an old saying that we get the kind of government we deserve. So to argue that 50, 100 or whatever South African gold industry experts should not be denied a visa to enter Australia in order to attend a conference is to forget the fact that the Government does represent the people. Of course, in South Africa the Government represents only a vast minority of people, who happen to be the very white people we are asking, through this motion, to be targeted. Our Government also ignores the fact that attendance by South Africans at this conference will, as I said, benefit the gold mining industry in South Africa and thereby allow some sort of domestic kudos to be given to the government of the day. Perhaps financial benefit will come from the increased expertise of those people who want to attend the conference.

The South African Government is to hang six young black South Africans, not because they have committed a crime-and that is clear-but purely for political reasons. So why should we not specifically ban from entry to this country for political reasons those gold mining experts? Botha is trying to deflect right wing criticism of him from within his own country with the upcoming elections in mind by killing six innocent young people. To condemn this action, as the Government and the Opposition are prepared to do by supporting parts (a) and (b) of the motion, but not to apply a penalty is effectively not to condemn. The Government and the Opposition are saying `We do not like what you are doing very much, but we do not dislike it enough to punish any of you, to punish your Government through the people who elected it-or at least, just a handful of those people'. It is not even the equivalent of a slight slap over the wrist. It is a really hypocritical exercise and a cowardly attempt to have a bit each way-to talk tough, but not to act tough.

Surely there comes a time when diplomacy is not enough. If the lives of six innocent young people do not mean that that time has come, I am not sure what would cause the Government or the Opposition to believe that that time had come. Denying visas to a group of white South African gold mining and technical experts-people employed in an industry where the very worst elements of apartheid have always been apparent-is a small enough action, but at least it is action and that is really what the Australian Democrats are calling for today. To support the first two parts of the motion, condemning the actions of the South African Government and then joining together yet again-the Labor, Liberal and National parties-to oppose the third part which calls for a concrete action for which the Democrats have been calling since the beginning of March when the issue was first drawn to our attention, is quite pathetic.

We have had calls from members of the Government and the Opposition in the past that visas be denied to a variety of people, as Senator Macklin pointed out earlier, including Australian sports people. On the other hand, we have calls to stop Ian Paisley, Palestine Liberation Organisation representatives and others from coming to this country. From time to time visas are denied to people whose presence is anathema to Australians for one reason or another because of the beliefs they espouse or the actions that it is believed they might take. This case is really no different, except that by not acting we are condemning six innocent South Africans to death because Government and Opposition senators are not prepared to do more than make noises about the hangings.

Even if, as Senator Button suggests, the action of withdrawing these visas might not be able to save these six people, we should bear in mind that it is quite likely-far more likely if we act than if we do not-that on some future occasion the abhorrent, racist Botha Government might think a second time before taking such an action and denying clemency which has been asked and begged for for these six young South Africans. It will be a vast disappointment to the Australian Democrats and many others in the community who are extremely concerned about inaction in relation to South Africa that once again this Government and the Opposition coalition have joined together and failed to support action against the abhorrent regime in South Africa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the words of my Leader, Senator Chaney, in this debate-that is, to support specifically parts (a) and (b) of Senator Macklin's motion, which refer to the intention of the South African Government to hang six black South Africans on Friday for murder. I oppose part (c) of Senator Macklin's motion, which deals with a different matter-that is, the question of visas for certain South African gold experts who are coming to Australia, I understand, for some conference in the near future. As background I stand here as a member of a party which I think has been an historical leader in the fight against apartheid in South Africa. I mention the former Prime Minister, who attained a world status in this area not only when he was Prime Minister of this country but also through his work on the Eminent Persons Group for the Commonwealth--
—First class work.

—As Senator Macklin says, he did some first class work. From that background I want to address these issues. In doing so I must first try to qualify, to some extent, what Senator Powell has said in relation to the circumstances of this crime. I do not want to put great weight upon it because I and my Party are opposed to these intended hangings. Nevertheless, Senator Powell did say some things that seemed, as I read at least parts of the judgment of the South African appeal court, not to be fair conclusions. Senator Powell said that they had `no direct responsibility for the crime'. She said they had committed no crime. Finally, she said that six innocent South Africans were condemned to death. On reading the appeal court judgment I do not think that those are fair conclusions to reach. I remind Senator Powell that the trial judge in this matter concluded, and it was accepted by the court of appeal, that in respect of six of those on trial-there were originally eight defendants, two of whom were acquitted-each of them had the intention to kill the deceased.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the first accused-and I will mention only a couple of them-the court of appeal found:

He was one of the persons who grabbed hold of the deceased near the fence between the houses of the deceased and Maile, and who wrestled with the deceased for the possession of his pistol. He was also the person who threw the first stone at the deceased as he was crossing the fence, which struck him on the head and felled him.
In relation to the second accused, the court of appeal said:

He was one of the mob which stoned the deceased's house before the first arrival of the police on the scene. He himself threw a stone which struck a window on the right-hand side of the house and broke it.

The judgment of the appeal court continues. What I am trying to say by quoting those findings is that these people have been convicted of this crime because they were actively part of a crowd that killed this black man in most horrific circumstances. They were therefore deemed to have had a common purpose. The facts of the case as accepted by the court in the first instance and by the appeal establish terms of that common purpose which I think would be opposed in the most strident terms by all in this place.

Having said that, I go on to deal with the broader aspects of the debate and what is happening in South Africa. Mr President, the debate on South Africa, as you are well aware, has been most frustrating. Those of us who have taken an interest in it and have used every opportunity given to us to urge reform towards the abolition of apartheid have been most frustrated. From time to time we have witnessed steps, albeit small steps, which we believe have been in the right direction only to be then disappointed by what seem to us to be backward steps-often frustratingly unnecessary backward steps.

We have seen a small but positive step forward towards dismantling some aspects of apartheid such as in sport and places of entertainment. We know that now almost all South African theatres have been fully integrated. We have seen reform in the areas of hotels and restaurants. At least now, under 1985 amendments to the liquor Act, racial discrimination in hotels has been abolished. We have seen some small steps forward in recreation. We know that the majority of local authorities have opened libraries, museums, parks and beaches to all races. We know of reforms in relation to interracial marriage and interracial sex, with the bans on interracial marriage and on interracial sex having been abolished. There have been some small improvements in relation to population settlement-we know there has been suspension of enforced resettlements-and also in relation to property ownership. I could go on; but that is not really the debate today.

What I am trying to say is that we witnessed these small steps forward only to be frustrated by what seem to have been significant steps backwards. I suppose in recent years that we really witnessed the most significant steps backwards in 1985 and 1986. None of us will forget the scenes emanating from South Africa of violence in townships that we saw on our televisions and of what seemed to be unnecessarily responsive violence by the authorities, the literally thousands who were then held without trial, and the hundreds of children who were held without trial-in some cases for many months without their parents even being able to find out their state of welfare or even in which establishment they were being held. We witnessed those horrific scenes, as you will recall, Mr President. Night after night we witnessed schools being closed in response to such violence.

Then we were finally frustrated by what seems to be the traditional ultimate resort of the South Africans when they are receiving international unfavourable publicity, which is a further clampdown on the media. We found that the world's witnessing of this abhorrent behaviour was suddenly forcibly curbed and we were told that we could no longer witness what had happened. That was in 1985 and 1986, which will go down as bad years in South Africa's history.

Those years were followed by 1987 which, again, I believe gave us some reason for cautious hope. Certainly, it was a time of more restrained activity in South Africa. There was less violence, but, of course, we know that it was under a national state of emergency and that the police and the military were still in the schools, so how much of that restraint emanated from a change of attitude is questionable; nevertheless, things on the surface appeared to be more peaceful.

In that environment South Africa went into the May 1987 election. We were pleased to the extent that the ruling party, the National Party under state President Botha, went to the people in that campaign with a dual plank: the first part, which is most important to this debate, was a willingness to negotiate with the leaders of all South Africa's communities towards a new system of power sharing under which no one group could dominate the others. The other half of the plank, which is consistent with this debate, was a strict enforcement of law and order to protect the stability of the country. Nevertheless, the President did go to the people with the prospect of moderate but continuing reform.

We were pleased that in the election campaign there were such independent candidates as Dr Worrall standing, which in effect supported the Progressive Federal Party (PFP), which was seeking reform to take place at a more rapid pace. As you will recall, Mr President, the election result was that Botha was returned with an increased majority. That was disappointing in that the PFP was in effect nearly wiped out. The Independents, including Dr Worrall, lost; so those who were advocating a faster pace for reform were unsuccessful. We then had to rely on Mr Botha's commitment to the people before the election. A worrying aspect that also became relevant to the circumstances occurring in South Africa at the moment was the increased support for the pro-partition Conservative Party of South Africa, which also occurred in that election.

In 1987 we also saw further movement in what became known as the KwaZulu/Natal Indaba, which we who look for reform in South Africa saw as a possible precedent towards some type of government by multiracial entity, a way in which the Zulu tribe in South Africa and the province of Natal could join together and find a formula whereby majority rule could prevail, with what all of us have seen as necessary in South Africa, that is, certain guaranteed rights for minority groups. We were hopeful that this might have acted as some guide to some continued reform in the future. Unfortunately, that does not seem to have come to pass. It seems to have fallen, partly because the plan was not accepted by some of the national groups within the community, and also because of concern expressed by the National Party that it allowed for majority rule. I suppose that in that concern expressed by the National Party we should have seen the sign that democracy in our terms is still a long way off in South Africa. So we saw progress and then we seemed to lose it.

Also last year we saw progress in initiatives taken by the Institute for a Democratic Alternative for South Africa. That was a successful attempt in the first instance to get together outlawed African National Congress leaders with leading academics and others from South Africa to try again to find a formula, to use their words, to achieve a breakthrough for hope. They met, discussed it and reached conclusions that a non-racial democracy was desirable. But, unfortunately, as with so many other initiatives, they did not seem to be able to progress it further. So last year we had these examples of some hope, in each case to be followed only by some disappointment.

That brings us to this year and the circumstances in which the Conservative Party and those most conservative Afrikaners have obviously increased their support within the white community of South Africa. We find that Mr Botha appears to feel that the pressure that they can bring to bear upon this Government should attach a greater weight than the reforms that he promised at the last election that he would introduce. So, unfortunately, this year we have seen a willingness by his Government to bow to these pressure groups and, therefore, his feeling of need for him to exhibit even greater strength by inhibiting what can be seen as steps towards multiracial democracy. We saw it only last month when out of the blue he and his Government banned some 17 different groups, trade union groups, the Congress of South African Trade Unions, together with some of the major black alternative political organisations, the United Democratic Front, and the Azanian People's Organisation. He banned their political operation and in effect put them out of operation for reasons that seem to relate simply to a need to assure the more conservative white community in South Africa that he is exhibiting strength.

The tragedy in this is that those bodies offered further hope for reform along the democratic path. If non-violent groups, groups which exhibit non-violent protests and engage in non-violent political activity are banned, how else are they to demonstrate their cause other than through the method which we all find abhorrent-that is, violence? Needless to say, President Botha's actions in banning those groups were condemned around the world. As a matter of interest, they were condemned by many in South Africa, including the churches. The response of some of the churches in South Africa was courageous. Mr President, you will recall that they said immediately that they would step in and take the place of the banned organisations; they would, in effect, fill the gap and allow peaceful protests, peaceful democratic action, to take place through that means. The Government's immediate response was to ban their organisation which they call the Committee to Defend Democracy. Again, not even the churches could join together to engage in political activity; they were also to be banned.

That brings us right up to date in terms of the environment in which the South African Government again intends to exhibit its strength this Friday. It intends to do what President Botha indicated at the last election-that is, to strongly enforce law and order. It will do so by hanging six blacks who have been convicted of murder. It is a distressing situation in that their death simply will put the cause of progress towards democracy and abolition of apartheid back another step. On each occasion on which a step is taken which quite reasonably enrages the black majority in South Africa-90 per cent of the community-their support for the mechanisms that President Botha claims to be wanting to establish is put back another step.

The execution by hanging of these six people will not solve the violence that occurs in South Africa. A lessening of violence will be achieved only by a more democratic system, by allowing the various communities in South Africa to have a say and to make a contribution in government and in the processes that influence every aspect of their lives. With that can come greater respect for authority. With greater respect for authority can come greater respect, which has to be earned, for the enforcement authorities. With that can come a lessening of violence and, therefore, a society that should be more satisfactory to all South Africans.

In those circumstances, the Opposition is pleased to join with others in this chamber in condemning what the South African Government plans to do. I suppose that what we are asking for is that State President Botha reconsider his decision not to reprieve these people. This is an opportunity for him to show a concrete sign that there can be a break in this violent tradition of South Africa. It is a sign that would be appreciated, I am sure, throughout the world. On this side of the chamber we have tried to adopt the carrot and stick approach to South Africa. We have supported the Gleneagles Agreement, for example. Where necessary, we have been willing to apply pressure when we think that it might produce a positive result. Also, we have been prepared for a little give and take, because if we do not give some credit where credit should be due, we lose an opportunity. I assure the South African authorities that in this circumstance where it has yet another opportunity to show that they are prepared to take a step away from violence, that they are prepared to reprieve these six people and say that this process of hangings that occurs so often in South Africa is not necessarily the best method of achieving an atmosphere that is conductive to democratic reform, they will receive the support and plaudits of those on this side of the House. In conclusion, we cannot see how banning South African gold experts will contribute in any way to the goal that we seek in this debate, and that is to invite and urge State President Botha to commute the sentences, thereby showing some tolerance and showing the world that there is another way, another direction, that South Africa can take.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to present some information that has not appeared in the debate so far. The Australian Democrats' motion calls for the Australian Government to condemn the South African Government for the impending execution of six people as they say there is no proof that the six contributed to a councillor's death. They have quoted from the appeal court judge's judgment on that count. It could be that the appeal court judge was quoted out of context when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It has not been proved in the case of any of the six accused convicted of murder that their conduct has contributed causally to the death of the deceased.

Undoubtedly he did say that, but when one reads and takes into account the full judgment of the court, one sees that the quote has been taken out of context. I wish to read the paragraph that is pertinent to the issue. It concerns the doctrine of causal connection which was examined in detail by the appeal court. The judgment states:

In the present case, on the facts mentioned earlier, there can be no doubt, in my judgment, that the individual acts of each of the six accused convicted of murder manifested an active association with the acts of the mob which caused the death of the deceased. These accused shared a common purpose with the crowd to kill the deceased and each of them had the requisite dolus in respect of his death. Consequently the acts of the mob which caused the deceased's death must be imputed to each of these accused.

Incidentally, I add that South Africa operates under roman law and not Westminster law, as we do. In coming to this conclusion the court applied the principles taken over from English law which have been part of South Africa's legal system for some time. It actually quoted the case Rex v. Ngcobo 1928 AD 372 as an early example of the principles involved. I bring that matter to the Senate's attention as to the first part of the Democrats' motion which is predicated on the fact that the appeal court has accepted that there is no proof that the six had contributed to the councillor's death. The story, as I get it from the speeches of the Democrats, is that an unruly mob approached the house of the mayor of Lekoa and torched the house to force him out. When he came out he had a gun which he fired once. He shot one of the attackers in the leg. He was then stoned to death. The first accused threw the first stone which felled the mayor. Another of the accused took the mayor's gun from him. The court transcript contains ample evidence and I hope that the Senate will allow me to incorporate it in Hansard. It is only a few pages in length. It is very pertinent in terms of associating each of the accused with the actual murder of the mayor of Lekoa.

The story that has been presented here is that these six are innocent of all crime and that they are being hanged after a summary trial. It was claimed that they are being hanged for the electoral benefit of the National Party in South Africa so that it can show that it has not gone soft in its administration of the law. The second part of the motion states:
Further condemns the South African Government for ignoring appeals for clemency from Australia's Foreign Minister, My Hayden, and from countries such as Britain and the US.

It may well be that those countries have debated the issue as we have here today, without having the full text of what the appeal court said in relation to the casual connection between the accused and the mayor who was murdered. I think that if one had to think of a word to describe South Africa-the land, its climate, its jungles, its animals and its people-the word would have to be `brutal' because it is a brutal country. We must remember that South Africa is an African country. Our interpretation of things here is entirely different from how they would be interpreted over there. The reason given for the moving of the first part of the Australian Democrats' motion is not correct. It is based on a quote which was taken out of context. Similarly, part two of the motion could have been based on insufficient information on which to debate the subject. Of course, the Opposition is opposing part three of the motion. I seek leave to have a few pages of the transcript of the trial incorporated in Hansard so that everybody may read of the close association between the six accused and the death of the mayor of Lekoa.
Leave granted.
