Excerpt from the Court Case

``I turn now to the role played by each of the accused, as found by the trial Court, in the gruesome events outlined above. Although accused Nos 5 and 6 are not directly involved in the present enquiry, it will be convenient to include them in this survey.
Accused No. 1

He was one of the persons who grabbed hold of the deceased near the fence between the houses of the deceased and Maile, and who wrestled with the deceased for the possession of his pistol. He was also the person who threw the first stone at the deceased as he was crossing the fence, which struck him on the head and felled him. (The first-mentioned finding was based on the observations of Mabuti, and the second on the observations of Mrs Dlamini. It was argued on behalf of accused No. 1 that there was a conflict between the evidence of Mabuti and that of Mrs Dlamini which could not be resolved, since Mabuti did not see the throwing of the stone by accused No. 1 and Mrs Dlamini did not see accused No. 1 grappling with the deceased. The trial Court considered this alleged conflict fully and carefully, as appears from the judgment of the trial Judge, and found that it did not exist. In my view the reasoning of the trial Court is unassailable. The fallacy in the argument for the accused is that it presupposes that either or both of the witnesses must be untruthful or unreliable simply because their observations did not coincide. Such an approach to the evidence is unsound. Mabuti and Mrs Dlamini were making their observations of fast-moving events from different vantage points, and there is no improbability inherent in postulating that accused No. 1, after having grappled with the deceased for the gun, moved off some paces and from there threw a stone at him. More-over, as the trial Judge pointed out, there was other evidence confirming the correctness of the observations of both witnesses. Some time after the events accused No. 1 took the police to the house of accused No. 3 with a view to finding the deceased's pistol. At that time the police did not know of accused No. 3's involvement in the affair. In fact accused No. 3 was in possession of the deceased's pistol, which he handed over to the police. This evidence, coupled with accused No. 1's false denial of it, showed that accused No. 1 knew that accused No. 3 had obtained possession of the pistol from the deceased and this confirms Mabuti's evidence that accused No. 1 was one of the group who wrestled with the deceased for the possession of the pistol. On the other hand, after the deceased had been felled by the first stone thrown at him, Mrs Dlamini heard him exclaim: ``Ja-ja, wat maak jy (What are you doing)?'' ``Ja-ja'' was the nickname of accused No. 1, but Mrs Dlamini did not know that, although she knew accused No. 1. This confirms her evidence that accused No. 1 threw the first stone that felled the deceased. In the result there is no reason for differing from the trial Court's findings that accused No. 1 grappled with the deceased for the possession of the pistol and that he was the man who threw the stone that felled the deceased.)
Accused No. 2

He was one of the mob which stoned the deceased's house before the first arrival of the police on the scene. He himself threw a stone which struck a window on the right-hand side of the house and broke it. When the police arrived and dispersed the crowd, he was affected by the teargas used by the police. He went into a yard and washed his face. After the crowd had re-assembled, he rejoined it in front of the deceased's house. He saw that the deceased was standing outside his house. He saw that the house was on fire and that it was surrounded by many people. He threw a stone at the deceased. It struck the deceased on his back. When the police arrived again, he ran away. (The facts recited above appear from a confession made by accused No. 2, a letter written by him from prison to the Minister of Justice, and statements made by him to a police lieutenant in the course of pointing out certain places).
Accused No. 3

He was one of the small group of men who caught hold of the deceased as he was running in the direction of Maile's house, and who wrestled with him for possession of his pistol. He was the man who in fact succeeded in taking the deceased's pistol away from him. (These findings of the trial Court rested on inference. There was no direct evidence that accused No. 3 was on the scene. Neither Mabuti nor Mrs Dlamini knew accused No. 3 and neither could identify him. The validity of the trial Court's inference was challenged in this Court. In brief, the evidence against accused No. 3 was as follows. On 9 November 1984 Detective Sergeant Wessels was taken by accused No. 1 to the house of accused No. 3. Wessels did not know where accused No. 3 lived; he was directed how to get there by accused No. 1. Accused No. 3 was pointed out by accused No. 1 to Wessels as the person who was presumably in possession of a pistol. Wessels asked accused No. 3 whether he had a fire-arm in his possession and the reply was affirmative. Accused No. 3 took a pistol from between some cardboard boxes, through an opening in the ceiling of his house, and handed it to Wessels. The pistol was exh 1 in the Court a quo. Accused No. 3 explained to Wessels that he had taken the pistol away from some children who were involved in riotous activities in the vicinity of the deceased's house on 3 September 1984. The pistol, exh 1, was proved to have belonged to the deceased. Apart from the fact that he admitted handing a pistol to Wessels, accused No. 3 denied the substance of Wessels' evidence. He said that he had told Wessels that he had only obtained the pistol on 4 September 1984, when he had come across a couple of youths arguing about the pistol, which, one of them said, had been picked up in a scrap-yard. He denied that exh 1 was the pistol that he had handed over to Wessels. He was unable to offer any explanation as to how accused No. 1 could have known that he was in possession of the pistol. The trial Court accepted the evidence of Wessels and found that accused No. 3 was an untruthful witness. On a perusal of the record I can find no warrant for disagreeing with the trial Court's assessment of the witnesses. Having regard to the nature of the lies told by accused No. 3 in his evidence, and particularly to the explanation that he gave to Wessels as to when and where he had obtained the pistol, coupled with his professed inability to explain how accused No. 1 would have known that he had the pistol, I am of the view that the trial Court was fully justified in drawing the inference, as being the only reasonable inference, that accused No. 3 was the person who had dispossessed the deceased of his pistol.)
Accused No. 4

She was one of the crowd that converged on the deceased's house before the first arrival of the police. She was given a placard to carry aloft, on which was written ``Arena Shelete'' (``Ons het nie geld nie''). When the police dispersed the crowd, she was struck on the head by a rubber bullet fired by the police. After the crowd had re-assembled, she was again part of it. She was standing in front of the deceased's house when he fired a shot, hitting someone in the crowd. It was accused No. 4 who then shouted repeatedly: ``Hy skiet op ons, laat ons hom doodmaak (He is shooting at us, let's kill him)''. Subsequently, when the deceased was set alight in the street and a woman remonstrated with the crowd not to burn him, it was accused No. 4 who slapped this woman in the face. (The argument on behalf of accused No. 4, referred to in the last paragraph of the trial Judge's judgment on the application for leave to appeal, as mentioned earlier, and repeated in this Court, that there was no proof that anyone in the crowd had heard what the accused was shouting, is without substance. Mabuti, who heard the accused's shouts, was standing at the time on the far side of Nhlapo Street, opposite Maile's house. If he could hear what accused No. 4 was shouting, there can be no doubt that other members of the mob, who were much closer to her, must also have heard the words shouted. Whether anyone reacted upon her instigation is a question relating to the general issue of causation, which will be dealt with later.)
Accused Nos 5 and 6

They were part of the vanguard of the crowd which ran towards the deceased's house and hurled stones at it, after the crowd had been dispersed and had re-assembled. They were not seen to have thrown stones themselves, but they were the leaders of the vanguard in the sense that they were running right in front, with the others, who were throwing the stones, following. Accused No. 6 was the person who was struck by the bullet fired by the deceased. He was hit in the leg.
Accused No. 7

He was part of the stone throwing crowd. He was amongst the people who made petrol bombs in the yard of the corner house. He was the man who poured petrol onto the kitchen door of the deceased's house and set it alight. He was one of those who pushed the deceased's motor car from the garage into the street.
Accused No. 8

When the crowd had re-assembled, he came across Manete and said to him: ``Hoekom is jy nie saam met die mense nie? Hoekom baklei jy nie? Hoekom neem jy nie deel daaraan nie? Want ons baklei vir die `community'? (Why are you not with the people? Why are you not fighting? Why are you not participating? We are fighting for the community)''. He was one of those who made petrol bombs in the yard of the corner house. He handed out petrol bombs to the mob and commanded them to surround the deceased's house and set it on fire. He showed people how and where to throw petrol bombs into the deceased's house. The people obeyed his instructions. He assisted in pushing the deceased's car into the street. Before the deceased was assaulted in Maile's yard, he (accused No. 8) was in Maile's yard, carrying stones in his hand. After the deceased had been set on fire in the street, accused No. 8 said: ``Kom julle, nou gaan ons na die Munisipaliteit se jaart''.

I proceed to consider the basis upon which the trial Court convicted accused Nos 1, 2, 3, 4, 7 and 8 of murder. The trial Court found that the mob intended to kill the deceased, and that the intention to kill had manifested itself at the time when his house was set alight. The following passage in the judgment of the trial Judge reflects the approach of the trial Court, which, in my view was fully justified on the evidence:

``Daar kan geen twyfel bestaan dat die skare die opset gehad het om oorledene te dood op die stadium toe sy huis aan die brand gesteek is nie want elkeen daar het toe besef dat of oorledene verbrand of hy vlug uit die huis en as hy vlug moet hy aangeval word. Toe hy wel gevlug het is hy onmiddellik ontwapen en daarha met klippe bestook tot hy daar roerloos gele het en om te verseker dat hy wel dood was is sy liggaam na buite gesleep en aan die brand gesteek''. (There is no doubt that the crowd had the intent to kill the deceased at this stage when his house was torched because all those present knew that the deceased would burn or flee the house and be attacked. When he did flee he was immediately disarmed and stoned when he lay motionless to make sure that he was dead he was dragged outside and set alight.)
The same approach appears from the following passage in which the trial Judge explained why accused Nos 5 and 6 were found not guilty of murder:

``Die Hof kan nie bo redelike twyfel bevind dat (toe) hierdie skare . . . alreeds die opset gehad het om oorledene te gaan dood toe hulle die eerste keer op pad na sy huis toe was nie. So 'n bevinding is ook nie bo redelike twyfel ons insiens bewys tydens hergroepering tot en met die gooi van klippe na die oorledene se huis. Op die stadium egter toe oorledene se huis aan die brand gesteek word is dit duidelik dat die opset was om oorledene ook te verbrand. Dit het almal besef, dat tensy oorledene vlug hy sou verbrand, en as hy vlug sou hulle hom onmiddellik in die hande kon kry en aanrand, soos dit ook geskied het, totdat hy oenskynlik dood was en daarna verbrand is.'' (The court cannot find above reasonable doubt that this mob already had the intent to kill the deceased when they first went to his house. Such a finding is also not proved above reasonable doubt when they were regrouping up to the point when stones were thrown at the house of the deceased. At the stage however when the house of the deceased had been torched, it is clear that the intent is to kill the deceased by burning. Everybody realised this, that if he did not flee he would burn, and if he fled they would immediately get hold of him and assault him as in fact happened until he was dead and burning.)

There was no evidence that accused Nos 5 and 6 had taken any part in the activities of the mob after the deceased's house had been set on fire. Consequently the trial Court found that it had not been proved beyond reasonable doubt that accused Nos 5 and 6 had the intention to kill the deceased.

In the case of all the other accused, however, ie Nos 1, 2, 3, 4, 7 and 8, the trial Court found that each of them had the intention to kill the deceased. It found further that all these accused had actively associated themselves with the conduct of the mob, which was directed at the killing of the deceased. On the evidence, neither of these findings can be faulted. In the case of each of these accused, the conduct described above plainly proclaimed an active association with the purpose which the mob sought to and did achieve, viz the killing of the deceased. And from the conduct of each of these accused, assessed in the light of the surrounding circumstances, the inference is inescapable that the mens rea requisite for murder was present.''
(Appeluitspraak pp 68-80)
(Appeal Court finding).
Summary by Court of events leading to death of Dlamini

``The town council of Lekoa, of which the deceased was a member and the deputy mayor, is a regional Black local authority established under section 2 of the Black Local Authorities Act 102 of 1982. Its area of jurisdiction includes Sharpeville. During June 1984 the council adopted a capital expenditure programme with a view to improving and expanding the amenities of the inhabitants in its area. To finance the programme it was decided to increase the service levies payable by the inhabitants by R5,50 or R5,90 per house per month. The increase were planned to come into effect on 1 September 1984. The deceased was known to have favoured the plan and to have pressed for its implementation. Many of the people of Lekoa were strongly opposed to the increases. Protest meetings were held and it was decided that on 3 September 1984 (which was a Monday) the people of Lekoa would stay away from work and march to the offices of the council to protest against the increases. On that day rioting and violence on a massive scale erupted throughout the area of Lekoa. The cause, or at least a major cause, of the riots was the increase of the service levies. Hordes of people went on the rampage through the streets of the townships comprising Lekoa. The houses of town councillors and many other buildings were stoned and burnt down. The deceased and two other councillors were murdered on that day, and also a councillor of the neighbouring area of Evaton. A senior police officer with many years' experience of riot control described the events as the most violent, the most widespread, and also the best organized riots that he had ever experienced.

The deceased lived in Nhlapo Street, Sharpeville. His house was one house removed from the intersection of Nhlapo Street with Zwane Street. I shall refer to the house between the deceased's and Zwane Street as the corner house. On the other side of the deceased's house, in Nhlapo Street, was the house of one Maile. In Zwane Street, near to the intersection with Nhlapo Street, was the house of one Radebe. The yard of that house was used as a place for doing repair work on motor cars. On the day in question a number of motor vehicles were parked there.

At about 7 o'clock in the morning a large crowd gathered in Zwane Street. They were singing and rowdy. They moved to the intersection with Nhlapo Street, then into Nhlapo Street and towards the house of the deceased. They pelted the deceased's house with stones. At that stage members of the police arrived on the scene in large vehicles. They dispersed the crowd by using teargas and firing bullets. After the crowd had scattered, the police spoke to the deceased in front of his house and tried to persuade him to leave. He refused to do so. He was armed with a pistol. The police left the scene.

After the departure of the police, the crowd regrouped themselves. About 100 people, men and women, gathered together in Zwane Street. They were singing ``freedom songs''. Some of them went into the yard of Radebe's house and siphoned off petrol from the vehicles parked there into containers which they took along with them. The mob moved along Zwane Street and turned into Nhlapo Street. The vanguard ran towards the deceased's house and hurled stones at it, breaking the windows. The deceased was in the house, together with Mrs Dlamini. Members of the crowd shouted repeatedly (I quote from the evidence on the record, as it was interpreted in Afrikaans):
`laat ons breek, laat ons breek, die huis breek en aan die brand steek'

The deceased and Mrs Dlamini opened the door of the house and went outside to confront the mob. Some of them shouted: ``Ons is op soek na jou, Dlamini, die `sell-out', wat met Blankes baie te doen het, of met hulle eet''. The deceased and Mrs Dlamini went back into the house and closed the door. The deceased fired a shot into the crowd, hitting one of them (accused 6). This angered the mob, which became extremely aggressive. A woman in the crowd, who was standing in front of the house, shouted repeatedly: `Hy skiet op ons, laat ons hom doodmaak'. (Theresa Ramashamola, accused 4)

In the meantime some members of the crowd were busy making petrol bombs in the yard of the corner house (accused 8). They poured petrol from the containers they had brought along into bottles, some of which also contained sand. The bottles, or bombs, were passed on to other members of the mob, who were told to throw them into the deceased's house. This was done, and the house caught fire. Mrs Dlamini fled and succeeded in reaching safety in the neighbouring house of Maile. The deceased's house was then surrounded by the rioters. Petrol was poured over the kitchen door and it was set alight. The deceased tried to extinguish the flames. The deceased's car was pushed out of its garage and into Nhlapo Street (by accused 7), where it was turned on its side and set on fire. Petrol bombs were thrown into the house from all sides.

The deceased emerged from the house, holding his pistol. The crowd in his immediate vicinity retreated. The deceased ran in the direction of Maile's house. Just as he reached the fence between the two yards, which consisted of a couple of slack strands of wire, he was set upon by a small group of two or three or more members of the mob. A scuffle ensued, during which the deceased was dispossessed of his weapon (by accused 3). As he was crossing the fence, he was felled by a stone which was thrown by a man (accused 1) standing a couple of paces away and which struck him on the head. As he was lying on the ground stones thrown by the mob rained down on him. Some members of the mob went up to him and struck his head with stones. When he was lying quite motionless, he was dragged into the street. Attempts were made to place him on his burning motor car, but each time he slid off it. Petrol was poured over him and he was set alight. A woman shouted that the people should not burn him. Another woman (Theresa Ramashamola, accused 4) slapped her in the face. As the deceased was left to burn, the crowd, which still numbered 100 or more, sang loudly and gave the Black Power salute. They then started to move off in the direction of the Administration Board's buildings.
When the police arrived on the scene again at about 9 o'clock, they found the deceased's house and motor car and his body still smouldering. The deceased was dead.

A medical post mortem examination revealed that the deceased was still alive when he was set alight, but that he had sustained two sets of injuries, each of which was fatal by itself . . . (and he) would have died of these (head) injuries, even if he had not been set alight. The other set of injuries consisted of burns all over his body. He would have died as a result of these burns, even if he had not sustained the head injuries.'' (Appeluitspraak, pp 61-68)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on Senator Macklin's motion. The Government and the Opposition have joined the Australian Democrats in condemnation of the South African Government for its decision to go ahead with the hanging of six black South Africans for the murder of a black municipal councillor, despite the fact that the appeal court has accepted that there is no proof that the six contributed to the councillor's death. Taking up what Senator Sheil has just said, I would like to read a paragraph from today's Canberra Times:

SPEECH.PARA: No evidence was presented that any of the six took direct part in the murder of Khuzwayo Dlamini, deputy mayor of the township. They were found guilty on the unprecedented grounds that they were part of an angry crowd, some of whose members stoned Mr Dlamini into unconsciousness, then set fire to his body.

The Government and the Opposition have also joined the Australian Democrats in further condemning the South African Government for ignoring appeals for clemency from Australia's Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden, and from countries such as Britain and the United States. It is indeed unfortunate that neither the Government nor the Opposition is willing to join the Australian Democrats in calling for the Australian Government to withdraw visas for the 50 to 100 South African gold experts as a practical demonstration of Australia's opposition to the apartheid system which allows this obscenity. This is indeed tragic when one considers that the black people of South Africa, and Namibia, which also has a regime which has legislated on the basis of a difference in colour and race-countries which must be an abhorrence to all true democracies-have exhorted our Government to take action which would isolate South Africa.

Despite Senator Macklin's appeal, neither the Government nor the Opposition has so far sought to put some other form of action in its place. This is indeed tragic because, whereas the sincere and genuine concern of the Government and the Opposition is not in any doubt, that concern in my opinion and in the opinion of other Australian Democrats would carry more weight if it were backed by some action. Likewise, at this late stage I would like to appeal to the Government and the Opposition to propose some other action, which I am sure the Democrats would be happy to support, to demonstrate their concern in a positive and an active way.

All honourable senators who have spoken in this debate have agreed that the execution of these six people is against the principles of our system of justice. These six people will hang simply because they were in an angry crowd and, in some cases, took some action in that angry crowd. I quote again from the Canberra Times of today:

The six will hang because they allowed themselves to be caught up in a few moments of community madness during a rent protest 3 1/2 years ago. They were sentenced to death for murder, not because they killed anyone, but because they were members of an angry crowd of demonstrators that beat to death a black municipal councillor seen as a collaborator with the Government.

Of course, that brings back memories of Sharpeville. It is 28 years ago almost to the day-it was on 21 March 1960-that 69 people were shot dead in one of the worst official massacres. A common form of graffiti-`Remember Sharpeville'-is now being replaced in 1988 by `Save the Sharpeville 6'. They are the six people due to be hanged on Friday. It is a horrible irony that it is once again Sharpeville that is serving to bring South Africa to international attention. Six people-probably innocent-are due to die on Friday. This also brings to mind, especially to those of us that are from Western Australia, the recent publicity in the newspapers about Mrs Sheila Suttner, who now lives in Perth. Her son has been in solitary confinement in Diepkloof gaol, which is near Johannesburg, for nearly two years without a trial. He has been an opponent of apartheid for some years and, indeed, has been in gaol previously. Why is he in gaol? He is in gaol because he is an academic lawyer and the Government knows that if it releases him he will continue to question the legality of what it is doing in instances such as that involving the Sharpeville six.

It is a curiosity of the brutal South African regime that it is indeed sensitive to opinion. It goes to great trouble to dress up its repulsive racist laws in the garb of judicial respectability. The Government in South Africa does not lock up its opponents without trial. First, it makes a law which allows it to lock up its opponents without trial for as long as it chooses. Are those opponents innocent or guilty? If there is no trial, who can say? In the case of Raymond Suttner there is no evidence that he did any more than publicly call for justice for all people of all races. The fact that Amnesty International has adopted Raymond Suttner as an international prisoner of conscience is proof enough that he is and has always been an advocate of non-violent change.

If a white lawyer can be held without trial for nearly two years, what can previously undistinguished black citizens caught up in civil unrest expect in the way of justice? The Sharpeville six have also become internationally famous. These six people have been condemned simply because they were part of an angry crowd. A man was murdered very horribly. No-one can condone that. But there is no evidence to show that any of the six people actually directly took part in the murder. Where is the fundamental principle that the accused is innocent until proved guilty? Nobody should need to have their innocence proved, because innocence is the basic assumption of civilised law.

As I said previously, the South African Government is curiously sensitive to the niceties of legal opinion and the good opinion of the rest of the world. Therefore, we have to ask: How can we best help put pressure on the South African Government to dismantle apartheid? I think that Australia must make it clear by boycotts and sanctions. We must maintain the sporting sanctions as specified by the Gleneagles Agreement. We must censure our cricketers who prostitute their talents by claiming that they do it only for the money; and we should not forget that Pat Cash played in South Africa, naively claiming that he did not know what was wrong with it.

We can also apply academic and business sanctions. For visas to be denied to these 50 or 100 South African gold geologists and technicians to attend a bicentennial gold conference would certainly demonstrate to the South African Government how much we abhor what it intends to do this coming Friday. The South African Government may be brutal and insensitive to the cries of its own people but it is intensely sensitive to international criticism and international pressure. If we do not want all of southern Africa to erupt, we must maintain the pressure as proposed in all three parts of Senator Macklin's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we are debating today is not law but, of course, violence. In the early 1970s when I was an anti-apartheid activist and an activist for the liberation of Zimbabwe, and working at the time with the Aboriginal community in Redfern--
—Look what happened to Zimbabwe.

—Senator McGauran interjects, `Look what happened to Zimbabwe'. I am sure I would much rather be living in Zimbabwe than is South Africa. While I was involved in those activities I got to see mob violence up close. In fact, I was not part of it but a victim of it. At the time I was privileged to host in my home Edison Zvobgo, who was then an activist in the struggle to liberate Zimbabwe with the Zimbabwe African National Union and the Zimbabwe African People's Union. Edison subsequently became, I think, Attorney-General in Zimbabwe.

SPEECH.PARA: We were all idealistic Christian pacifists. We were very concerned about the violent struggles for liberation. We discussed this issue with Edison, and Edison's response is one which I shall always remember. He said, `What we are fighting for in Zimbabwe is the right to be human beings. There comes a point in resisting oppression, there comes a point in being oppressed, where not to resist means to cease to be human. Just to remain human one has to stand up and say ``No'' and resist by whatever means one can'. That is what we are concerned with in South Africa. We are concerned with the response of Africans to violence and terrorism.

It seems funny that there are two standards. We have heard much debate from Senator Hill and Senator Sheil about the words in the judgment that is sending these young people to the gallows, and about whether the evidence is this or that. We have not focused on why the demonstration was held in the first place. Why were these people protesting? These people were protesting against the inhuman housing conditions in which they had to live. That injustice seems to have passed us by. Had there been justice and equality in South Africa, such a protest would not have occurred and a death such as that of the Deputy Mayor would not have occurred. For the benefit of Senator Hill and Senator Sheil, I quote the words of their former leader, Mr Malcolm Fraser, who said:
. . . apartheid cannot be opposed without violence. Apartheid needs not only the law but the police, the military and the bulldozers for its enforcement and maintenance.
Referring to the film about Biko, Mr Fraser went on to say:

. . . when people in this country condemn those like Biko as a terrorist or the ANC as terrorists because they seek to frustrate the government and to fight for its change, they should be clear in what they are saying. Are they saying that the blacks must remain enslaved? Such critics ritualistically condemn apartheid.
We have heard that in this debate today. Mr Fraser went on to say:

Nobody is bold enough not to. Such condemnations are empty and without force unless one accepts that the blacks have the right to use the only means available to them to escape the violence imposed on them by apartheid.

It was in the process of attempting to escape the violence imposed by apartheid that the demonstration occurred. So, if there is any common cause for the death of the Deputy Mayor, it is apartheid, not the people who were protesting for justice and adequate housing.

I remember common cause, violence and angry mobs in the days when Australia still supported South Africa and the Springboks were visiting this country. Some very violent and brutal mob actions were carried out by those who were then called rugger buggers but who I would more honestly call supporters of apartheid. It was mob violence and crowd violence. As a nurse I tried to fix up by means of first aid the beaten and bleeding bodies of those who had tried to protest peacefully against sporting ties with South Africa. I remind the Senate that it is now policy not to have sporting ties with South Africa. I remember well the angry mobs that seized upon and beat those of us who were demanding that Australia have no sporting ties with South Africa and those of us who were demanding some sort of just approach to the South African regime.

I heard Senator Button talk about knee-jerk responses. I hope that we will continue to seek knee-jerk responses to injustice. I hope that all of us are so concerned about injustice and inhumanity that when we see it we will have a knee-jerk response to condemn it. I would hate to think that we would have to be somehow beaten into consciousness before we saw that it existed. Senator Chaney said that we should not impose sanctions on South Africa and that we should not impose the particular sanction counselled in this motion. But what about the Olympic sanctions against the incursion by the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics in Afghanistan? I remember Senator Chaney's Party and his Government at the time being all for imposing sanctions, trying to convince us all that by not sending athletes to the Olympic Games we would not only end the invasion of Afghanistan but also see the defeat of communism in the Soviet Union. If the withdrawal of sports men and women from the Olympic Games was more than just a token gesture over the invasion of Afghanistan, the withdrawal of the visas for the goldminers and others who profit from apartheid would be more than just tokenism; it would be an action that would have effect.

Senator Hill said that there have been improvements in South Africa, that we have blacks in theatres and all sorts of wonderful things. But that is almost like saying that, just because we now give jobs to women and we now allow women in the work force, we should condone domestic violence and allow women to be beaten by their husbands. Just because there have been some improvements it does not mean that we have to condone and accept the violence of the regime.

Senator Sheil gave us his illustrious interpretation of the South African court's ruling and he concluded by reminding us that it is South Africa and, after all, it is a brutal country and we have to look at this in the context of it being Africa and, somehow or other, Africa therefore is brutal. I remind Senator Sheil that the perpetrators of the violence of apartheid in South Africa happen to be Europeans, not indigenous Africans. I would be remiss in my duty in standing here demanding that this Government take some concrete action to save these six human beings who are about to be hanged if I did not remind the Senate that at least in Africa these six were condemned to death by a court of law when we have an inquiry going on in this country where over 100 blacks have died in custody without the benefit of the judgment of a court of law. I would be remiss in my duty if I did not remind the Senate that this sort of denial of black sovereignty in South Africa is the same sort of denial of Aboriginal sovereignty in Australia.

Indeed, when we talk about sovereignty we seem to think somehow or other that what we have in South Africa is a homogenous European minority ranged against a homogenous black majority when that is not the case. The laws in South Africa are oppressive for whites. It is treason for a white person to write a book in South Africa which criticises the South African Government. There is a denial of freedom of speech in South Africa. There is freedom of speech in South Africa for anyone who wants to support apartheid and support the regime. It is treason in South Africa for white or black to condemn the racist apartheid regime. I will not go on for much longer as Senator McMullan is anxiously waiting to address us for the first time and I would like to hear what he has to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —We would like to hear him. Some of us came into the chamber to hear him.

—I will remain in this chamber also to hear him. I would just like to remind the Senate that what we should be concerned with here is not whether or not there is some legal argument about whether the Soweto six were legally or illegally condemned to death because the regime which condemned them is abhorrent; the judicial system which condemned them is abhorrent; and the system in South Africa provokes the sorts of violent responses that we saw in the demonstration. In fact, it is a system of oppression which we have seen time and time again where regimes provoke violence by their own extreme measures and they provoke violent responses to justify repressive laws and measures and states of emergency. As I have quoted the former Leader of the Liberal Party I will quote from the Australian Labor Party (ALP) platform which talks about this state of emergency. In 1986 the ALP platform condemned:

SPEECH.PARA: the renewed declaration of the State of Emergency by the white minority regime in South Africa and calls on all nations to take concerted action to compel the South African Government to reverse this inhuman measure and completely dismantle the machinery of apartheid.
That is what we are demanding-action to dismantle the machinery of apartheid.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to commence by thanking you, Mr President, the staff of the Senate and other senators for facilitating the arrangements which have allowed me to make my first speech at this time and on this motion. It is traditional, but in my case also particularly appropriate, that I should begin this first speech by paying a tribute to my immediate predecessor.

SPEECH.PARA: I came to the Senate following the retirement of Senator Susan Ryan, who had represented the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) and the Australian Labor Party (ALP) so ably since 1975. I am in no doubt that Susan will make an outstanding contribution to Australian literature and publishing in her new role. However, it will be a truly remarkable achievement if she can make in that career a contribution to equal that which she made as a senator. Very few people, when they end their career, can have it said of them that they changed the face of the institution in which they participated. However, Susan Ryan changed the face of politics and government in Australia. There is no doubt that in the more than 12 years during which she represented the ACT in the Senate, the situation for women in Australian politics was transformed-due in no small measure to her efforts.

It is interesting to note the Press reports when Susan was first elected. It was seen as a very remarkable, indeed unique, event-in fact it was a unique event-that there should be a feminist in the Senate, let alone one who actually said that she was a feminist. Now we have many women representatives in the Senate-still a long way from 50 per cent, so we have a long way to go, but a large number of women who are making a contribution to their various sides of politics. It certainly would not be unique for any of them to regard themselves or declare themselves as feminists.

We will never again face the situation that existed before the 1980 elections in which there were no women in the House of Representatives. On that occasion the ALP had three women elected, all of whom are still active members of that House. Indeed, one has become a Minister and another is the Speaker. They have been joined by many female colleagues, and we will never go back to the days of a total absence of female representation in either House.

In honouring Susan's contribution as a senator for the ACT, as Minister for Education and in her other portfolio areas, as an outspoken representative of the ALP on a wide range of issues, and as an outstanding representative of women, it is important to note that, significant as her contribution has been, there is still a long way to go in the area of equality for women. That it should be remarkable that we have achieved a situation where 10 per cent of our members of parliament are women, when 50 per cent of the population are women, indicates how starkly inequitable the situation had been, how far we have come, but yet how far we have to go.

I intend to make what contribution I can to continue the process of overcoming those inequities, both nationally and as a representative of the ACT, where significant and continuing problems for women remain. I recently highlighted one issue in my call for the establishment of a regional office of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in Canberra. However, there are other local issues, concerning, for example, the need for a women's health centre, and national issues such as domestic violence which deserve prominence in the ACT, equal to that which they receive in the rest of Australia.

That brings me to my role as a senator for the ACT. In the national Parliament the four parliamentary representatives of this Territory, irrespective of the party they represent, face a unique problem in balancing their local responsibilities with their national obligations. That is so because in the absence of self-government we constitute the sum total of the elected representatives of the people of the ACT. In any equivalent area, covering two federal electorates, with a population of more than a quarter of a million people, there would be, at Federal, State and local levels, between 50 and 100 elected representatives, both full time and part time, serving the interests of the population and representing their constituents. In the ACT that burden falls on four of us. Of course, I was conscious of that when I nominated for the Senate, so I do not say that by way of complaint, but simply to indicate the balance that representatives of the ACT will need to strike, at least until self-government is achieved.

Within the ACT I have given the issue of self-government top priority. Fundamentally this is a question of democratic principle. Any group of a quarter of a million citizens deserves and must have the right to elect those who make the decisions which affect their lives. It must have the right to have those decision makers properly and democratically accountable to them. In the month in which I have been an elected representative of the ACT, I have also seen very starkly the difficulty and, in some cases, the virtual impossibility of satisfactorily resolving conflicts without an elected, accountable government. There are still many hurdles to overcome in the achievement of self-government-most obviously, an agreement on the electoral system, but also matters to do with the power and nature of the self-governing body to be established. However, I believe that the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch) has set an appropriately fast pace. The agenda for change which he has set down, directed towards the achievement of an election in the ACT for a self-governing assembly by November of this year, is reasonable, achievable and appropriate, given any reasonable amount of cooperation from at least one of the other major parties represented here.

The unique balance of local and national responsibilities thrust upon a senator for the ACT is not, however, in all or even most circumstances an incompatible charter, particularly for a senator with a philosophical commitment, which I have, to the important role of public expenditure in determining the planned change and development of the Australian economy and Australian society. Of course, it is the planned development of Australian public expenditure programs which has such a great influence on the economic and social development of this Territory. It has that effect on the whole of Australia, but the impact is highlighted more particularly here in the seat of government. It is particularly important that this question of the planned development of public expenditure be addressed now as we are coming to the completion of the construction phase of the new Parliament House.

If I might divert for a moment, having recently had the opportunity to examine that building more closely, I can say that it is a great architectural concept, brilliantly executed. It stands as a tribute to those men and women who have worked so hard and so skilfully-in fact, I think it is fair to say so brilliantly-to implement the architect's concept. It is a building of which all Australians can be proud and I am sure will be proud. I am very happy to say that those with whom I have discussed it, who have seen or visited the building, already are proud of it as a great national monument.

If I may make one specific reference with regard to the new Parliament House, I was pleased in my examination to notice that the facilities for telecasting the Parliament have been included. I think that is entirely appropriate. Like other members of parliament I am sure, I have received a number of letters in response to the decision of the management of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation-although the people writing to me, I might say, do not blame the ABC-to transfer the broadcasting of Parliament to Radio National.

I think it is appropriate at this stage that we consider the principles which underlie any decisions concerning the requirement for or the possibility of broadcasting or telecasting the Parliament. At this early stage-perhaps I will change my opinion with greater experience-the principle which guides me in my judgment about that matter is that Parliament should be regarded basically in the same way as any other very important public meeting; that is, it should be available to all media to report, broadcast or telecast in any way which does not interfere with the proper conduct of the Parliament. However, there should be no obligation on any of the media outlets to report, broadcast or telecast those proceedings.

To revert to my initial point, as the Parliament House construction draws to a close, it is important that we face up to the employment and investment consequences for Australia as a whole and for the ACT in particular. I am not, however, as a consequence advocating that monuments and empty mausoleums should be built simply to maintain an artificial level of employment. However, there is a need here, as elsewhere in Australia, for working buildings-buildings that contribute to the efficient conduct of the administration of government and through which we can provide services to the people of Australia. What is needed is development, consistent with the Government's overall priorities, of a program of public investment and construction to maintain that wonderful body of skilled workers assembled at the new Parliament House and to apply those skills in the interests of the people of Australia. Obviously, there is a continuing demand here and elsewhere for office construction but, beyond that, I believe that there are major national institutions the development of which will assist this region and the country.

In particular I wish to refer to the possible development of the National Museum of Australia. I am aware that the Government is reviewing the Commonwealth's role in relation to museums and collecting and exhibiting institutions, and I think that is an entirely appropriate decision. However, the reaction of the people of Australia visiting their national capital as tourists to the opening of the Yarramundi Visitors Centre in 1986 has indicated that a satisfactory level of demand exists to justify the construction of the National Museum. In the six weeks from Christmas to the end of January, 13,000 people went to the Visitors Centre alone and in the last 12 months more than 50,000 people visited that Centre-before the museum itself has been established. The revised development plan for design and construction which has been developed by the National Capital Development Commission with the Council of the National Museum of Australia is such as would lead to the development of an entirely suitable and cost-efficient concept which could make an outstanding contribution to our national culture and, I might say, to our local economy.

But, of course, public expenditure, important as it is for the ACT, is a question of national economic priorities. In considering those priorities, I believe that it is important that attention is given to the proper development of the national infrastructure. In referring to this, I want to make reference in particular to the recent report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, which made the following important points. At page 47 of the report the Committee said:

The problem facing Australia in the provision of infrastructure during the next two decades flows from the fact that our existing infrastructure network is incomplete and ageing. Increasing maintenance and replacement costs are likely along with a continuing requirement for new work.

Added to this, there will almost certainly be significantly increased needs resulting from structural changes. The overall infrastructure investment need may be reduced at times by demographic and technological trends but it will remain substantial. The consequences of not adequately funding necessary infrastructure investment would, in the long-run, impose a serious constraint on Australia's economic development.
The Committee went on at page 50, in effect to conclude:
There may be argument as to what level of additional investment is required but the Committee believes that the first and most important requirement is acceptance that an increase is needed.

This emphasis on public expenditure and investment highlights one of the predominant interests which will influence my focus of attention during my period as a senator. Amongst these priorities are economic management in general and jobs in particular. I recognise in addressing both those issues that the question of investment is a key factor, whether that investment be public or private.

We must all acknowledge that the Australian economy is at the moment in a very difficult phase. The Hawke Labor Government has been confronted by major problems in economic management, both inherited problems and those imposed by international economic factors. The inherited problems were highlighted by unsustainable deficit and public expenditure commitments and by an unfair and inadequate tax system. To compound the difficulty of the Government's task in dealing with these problems in the context of a recession which it confronted on coming to office, there have been the international economic problems highlighted by the terms of trade decline but also including the continuing threat of international recession. In the face of those enormous problems, the Government already has a very successful record of economic achievement, highlighted, of course, in terms of the priorities which I have previously indicated, by the creation of a million extra jobs in five years. That is, total employment now stands at a level over one million higher than when the Hawke Government came to office.

The other outstanding achievement of this period to which I wish to refer has been the sustained benefits from the consensus to incomes policy-the accord. When the Australian Labor Party proposed in 1983 that it could create half a million jobs within three years and establish a consensus based approach to industrial relations and incomes policy, the knockers and, I must say, in particular those who now reside on the Opposition benches, derided those proposals as unachievable and probably even undesirable. As one of those involved in the development of the accord, I have been proud to see the contribution it has made to the creation of the one million jobs and also to the reduction of the number of industrial disputes in Australia to the lowest level in 19 years.

Despite these successes, we must all face the fact that the foreign debt and balance of payments problems facing the Australian economy require continuing adjustment. What I believe is important in that regard is that the program of steady adjustment developed by this Government is maintained. It is worth noting that this is the first real effective program of adjustment ever developed, in spite of 30 years of almost continuous government by our political opponents. The current program must be maintained so that the adjustment can be made without destroying the economy. Recent economic statistics indicate that that adjustment is well advanced. The trade deficit is falling, both in money terms and in particular as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP). At the same time the Budget deficit has fallen, unemployment has fallen to its lowest level for five years and inflation and interest rates continue to fall. To achieve those five goals simultaneously in the economic climate with which it has been confronted is in itself an outstanding achievement.

To this I would like to add the significant redistributive achievement of the major reforms of the tax system which made it fairer and prevented the tax avoidance which flourished under the previous Government. In particular, the introduction of capital gains and fringe benefits taxes has required many people to whom tax was previously optional to make their proper contribution to meet their social obligations. The Government has been able to use the revenue generated from those new and fair taxes to fund the family package which has transformed the lives of more than 100,000 of Australia's neediest families. Furthermore, these changes have been made in a manner which has created the potential for balanced, sustained, medium term growth. With regard to this, I would like to refer to the Economic Planning Advisory Council's (EPAC) paper No. 30 on Australia's medium term growth potential. At page 14, the report concludes:

Real wage flexibility in Australia has been broadly comparable to that in other industrial countries. Disruptive wage increases contributed to some relative deterioration in unemployment performance in the early 80s.

As I am not supposed to be controversial in my first speech, I will not refer to who was the government at that time. Further, the report states that the ability of the Australian wage system to support employment growth appears to have improved substantially under the consensus approach of recent years. In dealing with the assessment of medium term growth potential, the EPAC paper concluded that GDP growth averaging around 2.7 to 3 per cent per annum should be sufficient to hold the rate of unemployment at least stable, and hopefully for it to decline, over the next four to five years. The paper examines the feasibility of sustaining this rate of GDP growth in the medium term, given the requirement for continued adjustment to meet the decisive constraint of the balance of payments and in a manner consistent with the necessary objective of a moderation of domestic inflation. Its analysis suggests that, under a plausible set of assumptions, the required external adjustment is consistent with average GDP growth of 2.7 to 3 per cent per annum, a stable unemployment rate, moderate increases in real wages over the period as a whole and a stable real exchange rate.

To have the record of achievements already established in such a difficult domestic and international economic environment and to have achieved that with effective programs of redistribution while creating the preconditions for medium term growth and continuing to adjust to enormous external pressures is an achievement of which the Australian Government and the Australian people can be proud. It is for this reason, with many others, that I take great pride in joining with other senators in this new role for me in Australian politics. It is a matter of pride simply to become a member of the Senate and to join with those senators who have already given such distinguished service. It gives me great pride to represent the Australian Capital Territory, where I have lived for a number of years and where I now happily hope and plan to reside for many years to come. In particular, it gives me pride to enter the Senate as a member of the Hawke Labor Government, which has under its belt already a record of achievements of which, as I have said, it can be proud. I look forward with enthusiasm to the opportunity of participating in the program of reform that lies ahead.

Before concluding, Mr President, it would be very remiss of me if I did not take this opportunity to thank those, many of whom are here tonight, who assisted me in the campaign to win the selection of my Party to fill this position. I hope I can continue by my activities both in the electorate and in the Senate to justify their faith in me. Finally, Mr President, I reiterate my thanks to you, the staff and the Senate for facilitating the arrangements for this first speech. Having discharged this first obligation, I look forward to participating actively in the full range of Senate activities.
