SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for lunch I said that this Government, during its time in office, had brought forth both sound economic development and sound environmental conservation. It is important to remember that future generations of Australians will be blessed with both prosperity and a country with grandeur and beauty. As I said earlier, the Bill sets up further instruments whereby Australia's environment and heritage can be preserved.

SPEECH.PARA: In case it is thought that there is no great need to have regard for the environment, it is useful to consider a few facts, some of which are as follows: approximately 2,200 species of Australian native plants-10 per cent of the total-are considered threatened. As many as 25 per cent of eucalypt species are at some risk of extinction. Australian fauna, although distinctive, is not particularly rich in numbers of species, but 89 terrestrial or freshwater vertebrates-about 5 per cent of the whole-are considered threatened. Seventeen species of mammals are presumed to be extinct. About two-thirds of original tree cover in Australia has been removed since European settlement. Fifty per cent of tall and medium height forest has been cleared or severely modified. An estimated 75 per cent of the original rainforest estate has been lost mainly due to clearing for agricultural and urban development. Much of the remaining rainforest has been logged so that large areas of virgin rainforests are now rare. Although large in total area, national parks and reserves account for only a small proportion of the land area in Australia. Even a considerably expanded network would not be sufficient to provide adequate habitat protection and wildlife conservation. The next figure is significant: 51 per cent of rural land in Australia needs treatment for land degradation. A substantial portion of rural land in Australia is continuing to lose its productive potential.

It is in the light of that drastic situation that the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson) has moved rapidly, sensitively and with great effect to establish a culture of conservation in this country. That is what is needed. The salt that has degraded the land in my own State of Victoria has caused great havoc. There is an urgent need for people to have a sense of the necessity for preservation of our land. Unless that attitude or culture of conservation or love of the land is instituted, the soil in Australia can only suffer further and further degradation. This will affect not only the beauty of the place but, quite clearly, also the economic future of the country. Much work is being done in Victoria by government and by farmers, particularly in the north of Victoria. The waste of generations is now being turned back-and so it should.

When we talk of conservation let us remember that it applies not only to the forests, the beautiful rainforests of Queensland in particular-that has been much talked about today and will much be talked about later on-but also to the fundamental state of the soil on which we depend so much. The portfolio of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Senator Richardson, covers those areas and those aspects of life which are best calculated to develop in the community-hopefully, in the hearts and souls of each of us-the culture of conservation which, as I said, is necessary not only for the preservation of all those beautiful spots in Australia but also for the future economic development of the country and its present economic well-being.

To turn to another topic: much has been made of the Commonwealth's part in preserving this land. Much has been made of the argument that the Commonwealth is usurping the rights of the States, that the Constitution has been overthrown and that in some way the Commonwealth is perverting the system set up by our founding fathers. This Government has done nothing but obey the dictates of the Constitution. I think it is very important to remember that throughout this debate. This Government has conformed to the intent of the Constitution. It has had laws passed and has carried out the administration of those laws in complete conformity with the Constitution. It is probably worthwhile reading some sections of the Constitution and of the Judiciary Act. Section 76 of the Constitution states:
The Parliament may make laws conferring original jurisdiction on the High Court in any matter-
(i) Arising under this Constitution, or involving its interpretation . . .
Section 30 of the Judiciary Act reads:
In addition to the matters in which original jurisdiction is conferred on the High Court by the Constitution, the High Court shall have original jurisdiction-
(a) in all matters arising under the Constitution or involving its interpretation . . .

It goes on to say `in trials of indictable offences against the laws of the Commonwealth', which is not pertinent to the present argument. It is in that context that the Commonwealth has made laws. Those laws have been challenged by such States as Tasmania and Queensland. The High Court, as it is obliged to do under the Constitution and the Judiciary Act, has made the decisions it has. It is in light of those decisions that this Government has gone forward and done what it has done in the interests of the heritage, the beauty and the grandeur of this country.

For people, not only here but outside, to say, `This Government is usurping the role of the States; this Government is overriding the intent of the Constitution' is just not right. Those people who are wrong are those who shout from the tree tops that this Government is in some way exceeding its proper role. The Government has the constitutional basis to do what it has done. It has the legislative basis for doing it. It also has the moral basis for doing it. It has the right because it is doing what this country needs; it is preserving it against the onslaught that unfortunately occurred at the hands of our forefathers, who came here, some quite recently of course, to earn their living by the sweat of their brow in working the land. As a proposition that is not to be condemned; indeed, it is to be praised.

However, in working the land and in exploiting the resources that the land holds we must act sympathetically and with an understanding that this continent is fragile and perhaps not as able as other continents, where the soil is deeper and the rainfall greater, to withstand exploitation-I do not use that word in a derogatory sense. This is not a country that is able to withstand that sort of working to the extent that other countries are. This is a beautiful country. One realises this when one looks at the paintings of such artists as Fred Williams, who unfortunately died well before his time, Russell Drysdale and Hans Heysen. They should awaken in us the need to preserve the country as much as we possibly can.

It is in that context that this Bill comes before the Senate. It has quite properly aroused debate about the balance between conservation and exploitation. It has to be said in favour of the conservationists that if they go too far they will simply preserve what, hopefully, will later be used. On the other hand, those who exploit the land too much waste it to the extent that it cannot be recovered. One can look again at a State such as Western Australia where there has been such exploitation that perhaps only two or three crops have been obtained from certain areas which now are virtually deserts. If one looks at such situations one sees the great necessity for a new sense of the value of the land, the forests and the rivers that adorn Australia.

Considerable mention has been made of the forests in the north-east of Queensland. To some extent, in just talking of those areas, there is a danger the debate may become so focused on one aspect of the concept of the conservation that the general need for conservation will be overlooked. However, given that, it is interesting to look at what the north-east region of Queensland contains. It has great diversity-perhaps greater diversity than any other area in Australia. It contains 30 per cent of Australia's marsupial species, 60 per cent of the bat species, 30 per cent of the frog species, 23 per cent of the reptile species and 62 per cent of the butterfly species in Australia. Eighty per cent of Australia's bird species occur in the rainforests of the area. There are no fewer than 34 species of vertebrates that are unique to the area. So, at stake is not only the flora but also Australia's unique animal life if we do not conserve the land, the forests and the rivers in this great continent.

I turn now to proposed new section 17a. Much has been made of the powers that are to be conferred by this Bill, particularly the powers of entry. Proposed new section 17a (4) makes clear that the powers granted to inspectors under this Act are not unusual. People may argue that the purposes for which the powers are used-that is, the preservation of the environment-are not sufficient for the granting of such powers. However, the actual powers are unexceptional, and I think that ought to be put on the record. Proposed new section 17a (4) reads:
An inspector shall not enter an eligible place (other than a public place) . . .

An eligible place is defined as any land, building or structure, whether or not identified property or on identified property, but does not include a dwelling house. So, a dwelling house is not subject to search and entry under this provision. Proposed new section 17a (4) goes on to state:
unless:
(a) the consent of the person in charge of the eligible place or the vehicle has been obtained;

So, entry can be obtained, first, if there is consent. Paragraph (b) provides that an inspector shall not enter an eligible place unless `pursuant to a warrant issued under subsection (5)'. A warrant can be issued under subsection (5) only if an eligible judge is satisfied on information on oath by an inspector that it is reasonably necessary that the inspector should, for any eligible purpose, enter upon the place. So, if an inspector enters a place pursuant to a warrant, such warrant must be issued by a judge on information on oath or, under paragraph (c), the following conditions must be satisfied:
(i) the inspector believes on reasonable grounds that it is necessary to enter in order to prevent the concealment, loss or destruction of any thing; and

(ii) the entry is made in circumstances of such seriousness and urgency as to require and justify immediate entry without the consent of the person in charge or the authority of a warrant issued under subsection (5).

So, they are the three conditions upon which a person may enter land not being a dwelling house. Such entry may be obtained, first, with the consent of the person in charge of the place or the vehicle; second, pursuant to a warrant issued by a judge; or, third, in cases where there is an immediate necessity to do something to ensure that the provisions of the Act are carried out. That is not an exceptional provision. During the debate some moment has been made of it being an exceptional provision. I think it is proper to put on the record at this stage that that provision is very much in the mainstream of the sorts of provisions that are put in any Act in which some sort of policing power is needed to ensure that the Act operates correctly.

The provisions of this Bill are well and truly within the constitutional powers of the Commonwealth. The Bill contains no exceptional provisions in terms of the powers given to policing authorities. It is dedicated to preserving our great heritage-that is, the continent of Australia-which hopefully for many centuries to come will provide its inhabitants with a great standard of living, together with the feeling that they live in a beautiful, grand and magnificent area of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Conservation Legislation Amendment Bill which we are discussing today seeks to amend the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983, which was enacted by the Labor Government in the course of the Tasmanian dams dispute. That legislation, which was subsequently upheld by the High Court of Australia in the Tasmanian dams case, effectively prohibited any further work in the Tasmanian dams area. This amending legislation is part of the Labor Government's current plan to have the northern Queensland rainforests also placed under World Heritage listing. Many people from all areas of the political spectrum are not averse to seeing sensible conservation principles and protection enacted in this country. However, there are also many people who do not like to see the rights of individuals eroded and neglected just to satisfy the political expediency of the current Government and the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Senator Richardson).

SPEECH.PARA: That is exactly what this legislation will do: It will further erode the civil liberties of individuals who are specifically affected by World Heritage listing proposals. This Government is attempting to preclude legitimate appeals against such proposals. Rather than provide for an open appeals procedure, this legislation that we are discussing will effectively preclude appeals being lodged in the Australian courts. That is hardly the activity of a government that is supposedly in favour of civil liberties and open government.

The Labor Government's attitude to its environmental policy ignores its oft quoted doctrine of consensus. An article that appeared in the Australian newspaper on Monday, 14 March 1988 quotes the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories as saying:
The Commonwealth's power to protect wilderness areas against the wishes of State Governments is now well established.

That is certainly the case. The present Government has used its de facto environmental powers to ignore State government wishes and it has done very little to attempt to find a compromise agreement. It is that aspect that I regret about this situation. In the Minister's second reading speech he stated that the Government `has a record second to none in its commitment to the environment'. That is a surprising statement from a government that spends almost as much on landscaping the new Parliament House site as it does on soil conservation measures for the entire country. The Government stands condemned for that. What the Minister really means is that his Government is second to none in seizing the specific trendy issues, while ignoring other crucial environmental issues which affect the country's economic and environmental future.

By contrast, the coalition's environmental policy has consistently been one of compromise and consensus. Before I speak specifically about the current legislation, I wish to raise some points about the coalition's record on environmental issues. While it is true that we have not sought to court trendy environmentalists with the same passion and vigour as have the Australian Democrats, and latterly the Labor Party, and while we do not make the well-publicised national park walkabouts and indulge in the tree hugging sessions in which so many Labor Party politicians seem to indulge, I believe that the actions of the National Party and the coalition at the Federal level speak for themselves. It was the National-Liberal Party Government that established the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. It was the same Government that placed stage 1 of the Kakadu National Park on the World Heritage List and brought about the cessation of whaling in Australian waters. It was the National-Liberal Party Government that took the initiative in developing and endorsing the national conservation strategy for Australia. It was the National-Liberal Party Government that introduced the national tree program.

My Party, most probably more than any other political party, has a vested interest in conserving Australia's environment. Many of the members of our Party come from rural areas. They derive their income from the soil and from the products of the soil. It is in their best interests, if from no other motive than maintaining a sustainable livelihood, to conserve the soil, water and wildlife in Australia. I do not believe that, because farmers use the environment, that ought to put them at odds with conservationists. In fact, I regard them as being more aware of and concerned with the environment than the average Australian, particularly those who live in urban Australia, because the closest those people get to nature is when they mow their front lawns.

While the coalition is concerned with and about the environment and all that it represents, we are not in the business of offering bribes to win over the so-called greenie vote. We are concerned that there should be a continued sustainable use of this country's resources while ensuring that the natural heritage of this nation is preserved. We cannot afford the luxury of being single issue parties. We are in politics to achieve something for all members of the community, not to play cat and mouse with legislation in the upper House, not to accommodate one group at the expense of another. Therefore, our environment policies must fit in with an overall pattern for government, one that is balanced, affordable and workable. That is not to imply that environmental issues are not important. A lack of commitment on my part, on my Party's part or the coalition's part to introduce or to support legislation that is not in the best interest of Australia as a whole should not be taken as disregard for our natural heritage.

Many times during the animal welfare debate I pleaded for balance in the argument. That same confrontation, that same inability or preparedness to accept the other side of the argument that is common in animal welfare issues, appears also to accompany debates over the environment. Balance is a very necessary ingredient in a civilised society. Dialogue, discussion, compromise and a commitment to all those must exist, particularly in emotive issues such as the environment. Dialogue has been sadly missing on the Commonwealth's part in this debate. However, the reality is that we must all live in this world and, for that reason alone, compromise must be reached if we are to eat, have appropriate and desirable housing and clothing, and maintain a standard of living that we have all come to appreciate and enjoy.
I believe that the coalition's approach to conservation matters is reflected in the national conservation strategy for Australia which describes conservation as:

The management of a human use of the biosphere so that it may yield the greatest sustainable benefit to present generations while maintaining its potential to meet the needs and aspirations of future generations.
Thus conservation is positive, embracing preservation, maintenance, sustainable utilisation, restoration and enhancement of the natural environment.

Turning from the environment policy in general to the issue of forestry, national parks and World Heritage listing, which is the central issue in this legislation, I would like to make the following comments. A balance must come into the woodchip and forest debate. On the one hand we have a group of people opposed to the felling of any trees in certain areas for any purpose at any time. These same people live in houses at least partly constructed from timber and largely furnished with timber and they write their protest letters on timber by-products. On the other hand we have a group of people that derives its income and its livelihood from the felling of these trees. These people live in similar houses and depend equally on the use of timber for their every day needs.

Australia is a net importer of timber requirements and we must become more self-sufficient. That is being done through plantings of new species that will provide a range of timbers. Additionally, woodchipping makes a significant contribution to export income and provides employment and industry to a number of towns throughout Australia. Of course, it is very interesting that in the south-east of my State at the moment some 80,000 hectares have been taken by the Unsworth Labor Government. Jobs have been taken away and families and towns have been put under enormous strain as week after week they wonder where the food will come from for their families because this area has been taken away from the woodchip industry for a national park. This same fate hangs over other parts of the southern tablelands in the upper Murray. I know that people in Tumbarumba, Tumut and the Batlow region have every reason to be worried about what might happen to their region because of what the New South Wales Premier has done in the south-east.

The assurances that the Premier has given over recent years as to what would happen to national parks have not been followed through. In Australia we have some 40,000 million hectares of native forest and three million hectares of national parks. Many of these areas are unique, have virtually always been virgin bush and should be protected against development either by the individual or by the Government. I do not think anyone denies that. Until recently other areas in New South Wales were grazing land and I can see no merit in converting them. But I believe that Australia is not that large and not that unexplored that new areas of virgin land with particular characteristics that warrant preservation are likely to be found. Therefore, I cannot accept an argument for increased national parks. This is another issue that is consequent upon the establishment of more World Heritage and wilderness areas. The Government must have the political will to provide an adequate infrastructure that will prevent the destruction of productive land from vermin and bushfires when it locks up this land for national parks. The New South Wales Farmers Association has often called for more consideration but has had little response from the New South Wales Government in that regard.

Having canvassed those issues, I shall return to the legislation and point out where the coalition finds it completely unacceptable. First, the legislation states that the final say on proposals for areas nominated for World Heritage listing, or areas under Federal inquiry, or any area already under the World Heritage List, or an area deemed to have World Heritage values for which the Federal Government has already issued regulations, shall pass from the Australian courts to the international World Heritage Committee. That is totally unacceptable to me and to the people of Australia. This is taking World Heritage listing from a position of credibility to being totally alien to the average Australian. It is actually giving away our land. The impact of this is that there will be no rights for individuals or States to appeal to the Australian courts over any action taken. There is absolutely no reason why the Federal Government should remove any Australian's civil right to access to the courts. I have pondered on that and I hope that people will think about why this is happening.

If the Federal Government is so sure that its legislation is fair and reasonable it should have the procedures open and affordable for those people affected. For the majority of Australians, including the environmentalist lobby, the issue of World Heritage listing is one with which they have very little direct contact. At most, World Heritage areas are places to be visited on holidays. However, many people, both in the industry and individuals themselves, will be directly affected by this legislation. For example, the mining industry would have no legal way of protecting its vast interests in Australia due to the retrospective removal of grounds for legal challenges to existing World Heritage nominations. I quote from a letter from the Australian Mining Industry Council to members and senators which indicates the concerns of this industry:

Two aspects of the Bill are certain to erode investor confidence in Australia-the retrospectivity which will prevent the appeals to the High Court on current heritage proposals, and the uncertainty of compensation provisions for expenditure already incurred. The Bill is another example of an Australian Government moving the goalposts after the game has started and would, if passed, create great uncertainty about future investment.

Australia, the beautiful country that we all like to say we are proud to live in, has a Bill come before it that will put a great deal of strain on an industry which, if it is allowed to prosper, will create a lot of export income and do something for everyone's standard of living in this country.

The standover attitude of this Government also extends to individuals. There have been numerous occasions when individuals have been affected by World Heritage listing. The plight of the timber industry workers has been well advertised. I have already alluded to what is happening to other timber people in south-east New South Wales by a different government, the Unsworth Labor Government, which has shown total disregard for those people. However, World Heritage listing also affects individual property owners. I mention one example of a farmer who lost half of his farm as a result of World Heritage listing. One hundred square kilometres of private land may not sound much of the total of approximately 9,200 square kilometres of World Heritage listing in the north Queensland area. However, for the approximately 20 land-holders affected by this proposal it is probably the end of their livelihoods, with no guarantee that they will receive adequate compensation.

The effect of this legislation will be that these people will have no satisfactory means of appeal within Australia. There is an old saying that justice not only must be done but also must be seen to be done. I am sure that Senator Cooney, who spoke before me tonight, would agree with that-being the eminent legal person that he is.

The current Labor Government not only ignores justice but also will ensure that the citizens of Australia will have no opportunity of obtaining it. Honourable senators should think about that. To where will the people of Australia appeal if they cannot appeal to a court in this country? The Government is ignoring justice for individual Australians. Senator Richardson has gained his formidable reputation as the hatchet man of the Australian Labor Party. With this legislation he has used his old techniques on the population as a whole.

Another issue I wish to mention is the use of inspectors who will have open powers of search and seizure. These inspectors will have an almost unfettered right to enter onto a person's land and do almost anything they want on that land. It is basically tantamount to setting up another police force in Australia. The only thing that the inspectors will not be allowed to do is to enter into a dwelling. However, I suspect that anyone living in north Queensland would be concerned to have someone stooging around his house at night. It would not be quite as bad as having an inspector entering the house, but it would still be a bit of a worry to have him flashing his lights around outside. Even though the inspector will not in the first instance have the legal right to enter a house, I think it would be small comfort to individuals to have their every action on their own property subjected to scrutiny, and to have inspectors wandering around the farm seeing what was going on. Some people have called these gestapo-type inspectors Richardson's Greenshirts. I think that earlier in this debate Senator Puplick described them so aptly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Balderstone's Brownshirts.

—Balderstone's Brownshirts, as Senator Tambling says. I was told that they were referred to as Richardson's Greenshirts, but obviously they are associated with other shirts as well. It must be remembered that people who create monsters-I hope Senator Richardson is listening to this-are sometimes devoured by their own creations. I think that this monster that Senator Richardson has created in these greenshirts or brownshirts, these inspectors who will have such an unfettered right to enter properties, might come back and bite the hand that created them.

SPEECH.PARA: Just recently Senator Richardson admitted the error of his ways in relation to the Australian Labor Party's environmental policy. He said something to the effect that it was suspect. Recently the Sydney Morning Herald reported that Senator Richardson had traded off Labor's traditional position in favour of the middle class greenies. I suppose that has been evidenced in the results of the recent Adelaide election, where the vote was not quite what the Labor Party hoped it would be. Because the New South Wales Unsworth Labor Government has not been looking after its traditional base, the same result will occur in New South Wales on Saturday when the people of that State will make the decision that they have had enough of a government that panders to minority groups.

The other major aspect of the legislation is the extraordinary action on the part of the Government in accepting the jurisdiction of the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act. That means that the environmental impact assessment provisions may no longer apply to World Heritage areas. It seems absolutely extraordinary to me that the Government is not willing to have its World Heritage area in north Queensland stand up to the open scrutiny of environmental impact procedures. The only sensible conclusion that can be drawn from this is that the area does not have the intrinsic value that the Government claims it has. It is no wonder that we have this unseemly haste in pushing the whole proposal through in this Bill.

This legislation is reminiscent of the travesty of justice that the New South Wales Labor Government perpetrated when it removed the Darling Harbour scheme from the normal State Government planning and environmental procedures. That was another example of the Government taking strongarm and out-of-hand action against the community and pushing legislation through without regard for the consequences in the final analysis. Obviously, when this Government has things to hide it makes sure that its proposals are not open to public scrutiny. I think the people might want to know why Senator Richardson does not want this open public scrutiny.

Some parts of this legislation should be of concern to all Australians. The legislation ranges from a complete infringement of civil liberties, to giving the Government an unprecedented and open-ended power to control environmental policy in this country. The final indignity is that the Government's proposals obviously do not stand up to environmental scrutiny. Therefore the Government feels constrained to remove its north Queensland World Heritage proposal from the open and well-established procedures of an environmental impact study, as I said. I shall quote a section of the Bill that concerns me most. I refer to proposed section 17a (1), which states:
The Minister may, in writing, appoint a person to be an inspector for the purposes of this Act.
Sub-section (4) (c) states:
. . . the following conditions are satisfied:
(i) the inspector believes on reasonable grounds that it is necessary to enter in order to prevent the concealment, loss or destruction of any thing;
I repeat that the sub-paragraph refers to `any thing'. Sub-paragraph (ii) states:

the entry is made in circumstances of such seriousness and urgency as to require and justify immediate entry without the consent of the person in charge or the authority of a warrant issued under sub-section (5).
Sub-section (5) (a) states:
enter an eligible place and exercise powers under sub-section (2).

The perceived necessity to enter a property is all in the minds of the inspectors as a result of their wanting to have a look at something. One realises how easily the inspectors could abuse that authority if they do not do the right thing. Yet, it appears that no part of the legislation ensures that they will do the right thing.

This legislation is not needed in the Australia that we know. As Senator Puplick said at the beginning of this debate, it should be completely rejected. I ask the Australian people to look at the Bill and ask why any government should want to introduce a second police force into the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to emphasise that people who have Bankcard accounts should read the small print extremely carefully. If they do not, they could find themselves obliged to pay charges for which they never dreamed they would be liable. The instance that I draw on arose with a Bank of Queensland Bankcard, but I suspect that it is the same with all other banks which have a Bankcard service.

SPEECH.PARA: Many people pay their Bankcard accounts on or before the due date. This probably does not suit the banks because they are not able to charge interest on outstanding balances at their exorbitant rate of 21 per cent per annum. Nevertheless, the banks are not entirely out of pocket. They charge service fees of up to 4 per cent of Bankcard sales to retailers who allow customers to pay by way of Bankcard. Suppose, for example, a person pays a dentist's bill of $100 by Bankcard. The bank concerned extracts about $2 and pays the remainder to the dentist.

Let us come back to the person who likes to pay a Bankcard account before the due date. What happens if that person for some reason is a day late with the payment? This happened in the case which prompted my remarks tonight. The person was not wilfully one day late. Because of an upsetting family illness, she was not able to go to the bank on the last day on which payment was required. She was not particularly concerned as the daily rate of interest was shown on the front of her Bankcard account as 0.05753 per cent per day. At that rate the interest for one day would not amount to much.

She paid on the next day and expected to see a small interest charge on her next statement. But that was not so. She was astounded to find a much larger service charge. Perplexed, she telephoned the credit card department of her bank. She was told that a condition of using the card was that if a payment was received late, a charge of 1.75 per cent of the total account was charged immediately, in addition, of course, to the obligatory charge of 0.05753 per cent per day. That is not a bad effort for one day; it is equivalent to about 660 per cent per annum. That is the type of charge that would have made Shylock blush. Sure enough, in the print on the back of the Bankcard account this condition was spelt out. Those who regularly pay by the due date could be excused for not knowing of its existence. I must admit that I did not know. I had expected that if I were ever late with my Bankcard payment, I would be looking at an interest charge of 0.05753 per cent per day. I, too, had not read the small print.

So what is the moral to this incident? It is that if a person uses a Bankcard and is a `pay by the due date' customer, that person should not be late, irrespective of the circumstances. If people are late, they should expect to be hit for six. But there is an interesting postscript to this story. When the person to whom I referred was inquiring about her excessive service charge, she was told that payment on the due date was no longer satisfactory. She was told that it takes 24 hours for funds paid into a bank to get into the system. One has to pay at least a day before the due date or the payment will be considered late. What is the point of having a due date if that date is too late for payment? In these days of electronic transfer, why does it take 24 hours for an amount paid into a bank to be credited in that bank's Bankcard system? Perhaps someone is playing the short term money market. It is no wonder that I make frequent use of a different credit card. I find it much more user friendly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about the problem faced by a former Australian Capital Territory prisoner, Mr Ray O'Shannassy, before his case passes into the annals of an urban myth within bureaucratic ranks. His political campaign of one-person occupation of parliamentary and ministerial offices has upset some members and senators and their staff and, of course, the Public Service. He has asked me to make representations on his behalf to the Minister for the Arts and Territories (Mr Punch), which I have done. At all times in his dealings with me, he has not caused me or my staff any harassment and he has not conducted himself markedly differently from any of the many and varied constituents that have passed through my office. I believe him to be a non-violent person in relation to other human beings. However, that is not the point of my contribution tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: What I want to draw attention to is the source of Mr O'Shannassy's agitation. It comes about because of his concern that the Commonwealth, under its Removal of Prisoners (Territories) Act 1923, has not fulfilled its obligations in regard to returning former Australian Capital Territory prisoners. I am more specifically concerned with section 8 (3) which states:
Where-
(a) a person has been removed to a State or Territory in pursuance of this Act;
(b) he is discharged in that State or Territory at the expiration of his sentence . . .
(d) his return to the Territory from which he was removed would not be unlawful,

he is entitled, on making application in such manner and within such time as is prescribed, to be sent free of cost from the place at which he was discharged or released from custody to the Territory from which he was removed.

The Commonwealth's usual method of discharging the obligation to an Australian Capital Territory prisoner has been to provide a free rail voucher from the New South Wales Corrective Services Commission. The cost of this has then been reimbursed by the Commonwealth under longstanding arrangements. However, this is not always a totally adequate arrangement, as has been demonstrated in Mr O'Shannassy's case. Mr O'Shannassy claims that he was released from Goulburn gaol on 24 January 1984 and given a rail voucher by prison authorities. He exchanged this for a train and seat ticket at the Goulburn railway station. When he boarded the train, he found that the seat allocated to him was occupied. His attempts to have the train conductor and station master secure him a seat were unsuccessful. Mr O'Shannassy's attempts to secure alternative transport to Canberra-by sitting in at the station master's office and later the rail superintendent's office-failed. I point out that that is the way that Mr O'Shannassy, in an Irish way, fights these issues. But he was not successful. Indeed, he was arrested on three occasions and on the last occasion he alleges that he was assaulted by a railway constable.

Mr O'Shannassy has had a lifetime of political activism for social change. His sit-ins and protests have led him into an ongoing campaign of agitation against both State and Federal Government authorities in connection with this issue. Mr O'Shannassy also faces a series of ongoing court cases as a result of his campaign. This should not cloud the concern that Mr O'Shannassy has about the return of released prisoners to the Australian Capital Territory. That is the point I want to emphasise to the Minister for Resources (Senator Cook), who is in the chamber tonight.

My reading of the Act suggests that it is the Commonwealth's responsibility to ensure the safe return of prisoners to the Australian Capital Territory upon release from the gaol gate. Some of the administrative arrangements following release could be improved and modernised. That is what I put to the Minister tonight. For example, after Mr O'Shannassy's train problems he was provided with a free bus ticket; but, again, there was not a seat for him. Subsequent inquiries revealed that the particular bus company did not have a seat allocation system, which highlights the vagaries of the transport system.

I ask the Minister: Why cannot the Commonwealth negotiate an adequate and cooperative administrative system with State governments so that a ticket and a seat on rail or bus is assured? The voucher system not only does not provide a guaranteed seat on public transport, as I have indicated in Mr O'Shannassy's case; it also leaves a former-I stress former-prisoner who has served his or her time to carry a tag in the form of a Corrective Services voucher. It is exactly that tag that could influence the behaviour of other people towards treating a released prisoner in a contemptuous way.

The current New South Wales State election campaign highlights how cynical and opportunistic coalition party politicians capitalise on hostile feelings within the community towards prisoners. I am very conscious of the old slogan that there are no votes in prison reform. We need only look at Mr Greiner's backdown on his plan to introduce a mandatory life sentence for murder less than 24 hours after it was announced. So I know that there is a problem in this area.

Another consideration in this issue must be that released prisoners may not have much money, which was the case for Mr O'Shannassy as it is for many others. Mr O'Shannassy has suffered two heart attacks and a stroke and yet no consideration was given to his health problems when releasing him. This stresses the point that each prisoner needs individual attention when release arrangements are made. The New South Wales Corrective Services Commission has stated that a released prisoner can make private arrangements. But what if the prisoner has no family or friends available to assist? The Commission has advised that it is not usual procedure for it to provide transport for prisoners from the goal gate. It advises that a welfare officer or a representative of the Civil Rehabilitation Committee could arrange transport if the individual prisoner requested it. I put to the Minister: could not the goal clerk or other administrator make adequate arrangements? Surely there are not too many Australian Capital Territory prisoners being released each day from New South Wales gaols. Although I have referred to Goulburn they are being released from gaols throughout New South Wales.

Whose responsibility is the safe return of released prisoners? On my reading of the Act, it is the Commonwealth's responsibility, as I have suggested. I ask the Minister to look into the matter and see whether a better arrangement can be made. Finally, I point out that Mr O'Shannassy has represented workers, as a trade unionist, people without housing in Canberra and now gaoled persons. I believe that the first step in trying to solve the problem might be to recognise that he has something in saying that prisoners should be returned adequately to Canberra from any gaol in any State.
